courses.subject: CS
courses.title: Special Topics in Computer Science
courses.description: Topics decided upon by faculty will vary within the area of study.
courses.repeatStatus: Can be repeated multiple times for credit

courses.subject: CT
courses.title: Network Administration I
courses.description: Students gain an understanding of terminology, technology, and issues involved in implementing networks. Topic include: understanding the OSI 7 layer model; concepts of servers and clients; network hardware/software functions; basics of TCP/IP protocol, main types of network topologies (bus, ring, star and mesh); and share and access network resources (files, printers, etc.).
courses.prerequisites: INFO 101 [Min Grade: D]

courses.subject: CT
courses.title: Server I
courses.description: Introduces administration and management of Windows operating system. Topics include operating systems installation, configuration, directory services, data storage subsystems, troubleshooting and problem determination of server. In addition the course will cover redundancy, upgrading, and disaster recovery.
courses.prerequisites: INFO 101 [Min Grade: D]

courses.subject: CT
courses.title: Information Technology Security I
courses.description: Surveys information security topics; familiarizes students with the technologies and policies that support confidentiality, integrity and availability. Industry standards for security architecture, operational security, policy and governance are covered and provides the foundations for further study of information security.

courses.subject: CT
courses.title: Open Server I
courses.description: Introduces administration of open source operating systems and management of open servers. Topics covered include the boot process and fundamental server concepts related to processing, memory and storage. Addresses use of a command line interface to manage processes, modify file permissions, examine configuration settings, and run utilities for server administration.

courses.subject: CT
courses.title: Computer Forensics I: Fundamentals
courses.description: This course presents the theory, methodology and hands-on labs necessary for students to become competent in the basics of computer forensics. Topics covered include: understanding computer investigations, the investigators, laboratory, current forensics tools, digital evidence controls and processing crime.

courses.subject: CT
courses.title: IT Security Awareness
courses.description: This course explores the challenges IT security teams face when trying to mitigate threats targeting the human element within their organizations. IT Security Awareness introduces students to techniques and concepts that threaten security of organizations by targeting their human assets.

courses.subject: CT
courses.title: Information Technology Security II
courses.description: Focuses on securing digital infrastructure by examining threats, vulnerabilities, and technologies used to prevent cyber attacks such as: encryption, security devices, software, authentication and identity protocols. Hands-on labs demonstrate the use of tools and techniques discussed in the course.
courses.prerequisites: CT 140 [Min Grade: D] and CT 201 [Min Grade: D]

courses.subject: CT
courses.title: Open Server II
courses.description: Presents an in depth study of server administration utilizing the Linux Operating System. Topics covered include: shell environments, shell program structures, executions, variables, positional parameters, special shell variables, and shell programming statements. In addition the course will examine shell conditional statements, looping constructs, interrupt handling, and debugging tools.
courses.prerequisites: CT 210 [Min Grade: D]

courses.subject: CT
courses.title: Access Control and Intrusion Detection Technology
courses.description: Fundamental theory and methodology of intrusion detection systems. Using intrusion detection systems to secure corporate and personal networks against attacks. Hands-on laboratory experience using an in-depth, open-source network intrusion detection system.
courses.prerequisites: CT 420 [Min Grade: D] or CT 301 [Min Grade: D]

courses.subject: CT
courses.title: Server II
courses.description: Presents an in depth study of Windows server operating system and active directory. Topics include installation, implementation, administration of resources, monitoring, troubleshooting techniques. In addition, the course will examine Windows based network management tools, high availability and disaster recovery.
courses.prerequisites: CT 200 [Min Grade: D]

courses.subject: CT
courses.title: Network Administration II
courses.description: Course covers both theoretical knowledge and hands-on exercises for networking using CISCO hardware. Topics include: Extending Switched Networks with VLANS; Determining IP Traffic with Access Lists; Establishing Point-to-Point Connections; and Establishing Frame Relay Connections.
courses.prerequisites: CT 140 [Min Grade: D]

courses.subject: CT
courses.title: Mobile Applications
courses.description: Provides students with an understanding of mobile technologies and the components for building and testing mobile applications. Topics covered include: mobile frameworks, plugins, mobile device storage, visual design and user interfaces for mobile applications, device sensors, and compression.
courses.prerequisites: INFO 152 [Min Grade: D] or CS 171 [Min Grade: D]

courses.subject: CT
courses.title: Virtual Environments and Cloud Security
courses.description: This course explores various models of virtual servers, storage, networks and levels of cloud computing. Students will learn how to apply best practice solutions to secure virtual environments and the different levels of cloud computing.
courses.prerequisites: CT 200 [Min Grade: D] and CT 210 [Min Grade: D]

courses.subject: CT
courses.title: Wireless Network Security Technology
courses.description: Theory, methodology and hands-on labs relating to the unique security issues of Wireless Networks. Limitations and risks of Wireless Networks. Use of audit and exploit tools to discover security flaws. Protocol and signal vulnerabilities. Methods to secure such vulnerabilities.
courses.prerequisites: CT 420 [Min Grade: D] or CT 301 [Min Grade: D]

courses.subject: CT
courses.title: Network Auditing Tools
courses.description: Theory, methodology and hands-on labs relating to Network Auditing. The course relies on advanced multi-functional network auditing tools to uncover Network Security problems, with the purpose of eliminating these vulnerabilities.
courses.prerequisites: CT 420 [Min Grade: D] or CT 301 [Min Grade: D]

courses.subject: CT
courses.title: Applied Cryptography
courses.description: This course presents the theory, methods, strengths, weaknesses, and effective strategies necessary for students to acquire a fundamental knowledge of Cryptography and Stenography. This is a hands-on course utilizing several tools and software programs. Emphasis is placed on formulating effective strategies, such as when and how to protect computer data.

courses.subject: CT
courses.title: Information Technology Security Risk Assessment
courses.description: This course addresses risk management methodology, the specific procedures for determining assets valuation, vulnerabilities, and threats. Risk migration methods that security professional use to protect valuable IT assets will also be studies. Issues, designed to foster critical thinking, are explored, as well as the standardized approaches to risk management.

courses.subject: CT
courses.title: Network Security
courses.description: This class focuses on the security aspects of networks. Topics covered: intrusion detection, VPN, and Firewalls. This course is designed to provide students with the necessary skills and information aligned with Securing Networks.
courses.prerequisites: CT 330 [Min Grade: D]

courses.subject: CT
courses.title: Information Technology Security Policies
courses.description: This course presents the theory and legal issues necessary for students to acquire fundamental knowledge of Computer Policies for information Security. Topics covered include: E-mail, Employee Privacy, Labor Organization Activities (Fair Use), Avoiding Discrimination and Harassment, Copyright, Defamation, Spamming, Trade Secrets & Confidential Information, Attorney-Client communication via E-mail, Computer Security, Preventing Waste of a Computer Resources, Essentials for Good Policy, and Ensuring Compliance.

courses.subject: CT
courses.title: Ethical Hacking and Penetration Testing
courses.description: This course provides students with the opportunity to learn hands-on techniques to protect and secure their information-critical infrastructure against cyber-attacks, viruses, worms, and other system cyber vulnerability weaknesses that pose significant threat to organizational systems.
courses.restrictions: Can enroll if classification is Junior or Senior.

courses.subject: CT
courses.title: Disaster Recovery and Continuity Planning
courses.description: Disaster Recovery & Continuity Planning specific to Emergency Recovery Procedures. Techniques for development of disaster recovery plans, procedures and testing methods. Strategies used by businesses to assure that sensitive data will not be lost in the event of a disaster. Techniques used to manage potential risk within multiple environments.

courses.subject: CT
courses.title: Information Technology Security Systems Audits
courses.description: This course presents the theory, methodology, procedures and hands-on labs necessary for students to acquire a fundamental working knowledge of IT System Audits. Students learn how to discover system vulnerabilities with proper audit procedures, and how to document their findings properly for upper management.
courses.prerequisites: CT 420 [Min Grade: D] or CT 301 [Min Grade: D]

courses.subject: CT
courses.title: Senior Project I
courses.description: This course is an independent project which small student teams determines and scopes an appropriate computing technology project that can be completed within the constraints of time and resources under faculty guidance. The objective of the course is to provide specifications and requirements for the team project.
courses.prerequisites: INFO 324 [Min Grade: D]
courses.restrictions: Can enroll if classification is Senior.

courses.subject: CT
courses.title: Senior Project II
courses.description: This course is a continuation of Senior Project I. In this course, student-teams are required to implement their project specifications and requirements developed in the previous course.
courses.prerequisites: CT 491 [Min Grade: D]
courses.restrictions: Can enroll if classification is Senior.

courses.subject: CT
courses.title: Independent Study in CST
courses.description: Self-directed within the area of study requiring intermittent consultation with a designated instructor.
courses.repeatStatus: Can be repeated multiple times for credit

courses.subject: CT
courses.title: Independent Study in CST
courses.description: Self-directed within the area of study requiring intermittent consultation with a designated instructor.
courses.repeatStatus: Can be repeated multiple times for credit

courses.subject: CT
courses.title: Independent Study in CST
courses.description: Provides individual study or research in computing and security technology with faculty supervision. This course may be repeated for credit.
courses.repeatStatus: Can be repeated 2 times for 6 credits

courses.subject: CT
courses.title: Independent Study in CST
courses.description: Self-directed within the area of study requiring intermittent consultation with a designated instructor.
courses.repeatStatus: Can be repeated multiple times for credit

courses.subject: DSCI
courses.title: Recommender Systems
courses.description: Recommender systems are electronic commerce information filtering systems to predict items that the users may have interest in. The goal of this course is to provide an overview of recommender systems, including content-based and collaborative algorithms for recommendation, programming of recommender systems, and evaluation and metrics for recommender systems. The course introduces all relevant topics of Recommender Systems: overview, non-personalized recommendation, content-based recommending, neighborhood-based collaborative filtering, recommender system evaluation and advanced topics. Students will gain hands-on experiences with assignments and a term project.
courses.prerequisites: INFO 212 [Min Grade: D]

courses.subject: DSCI
courses.title: Applied Deep Learning
courses.description: The goals of this course are to introduce basic theory of deep learning in data science applications, to understand how deep learning algorithms work at a high level, and to apply deep learning algorithms to key data science problems in different disciplines. The course introduces all relevant topics in deep learning: neural networks, backpropagation, convolution neural networks, recurrent neural networks and deep reinforcement learning. Students will be exposed to various representative algorithms in the concept level and learn their trade-offs. Students will gain hands-on experiences with assignments and a term project. Students will be prepared to attack new problems using various deep learning methods.
courses.prerequisites: INFO 213 [Min Grade: D] and MATH 201 [Min Grade: D]

courses.subject: INFO
courses.title: Introduction to Computing and Security Technology
courses.description: Explores the infrastructure that makes current information and communication technology possible. Introduces foundational concepts of servers, networks, databases, and the Web. Addresses security and usability considerations that cut across all computing technology. Approaches computing technology from the perspective of system administrators who plan, manage, operate, and monitor large scale computing infrastructure. Covers emerging technologies including pervasive computing, continuous integration, virtualization, and the Internet of things. Explores professional opportunities in this high demand area.

courses.subject: INFO
courses.title: Introduction to Information Systems
courses.description: Introduces students to major types of information systems and their development and their use in organizations. Emphasizes ways in which information systems can be used to help individuals and organizations meet their goals. Assumes basic knowledge of computing concepts.

courses.subject: INFO
courses.title: Introduction to Data Science
courses.description: A first course in data science. Introduces data science as a field, describes the roles and services that various members of the community play and the life cycle of data science projects. Provides an overview of common types of data, where they come from, and the challenges that practitioners face in the modern world of “Big Data.” Provides an introduction to the interdisciplinary mixture of skills that the practice requires.

courses.subject: INFO
courses.title: Introduction to Human-Computer Interaction
courses.description: Introduces the field of human-computer interaction, with a broad scope that exposes students to a variety of approaches for conceptualizing, designing, and evaluating user interfaces and user experiences. Focuses on using design thinking to define problems and solutions, and developing skills for critiquing interactive systems. Topics include interaction design principles, user experience research, usability evaluation, and novel interaction paradigms.

courses.subject: INFO
courses.title: Introduction to Ubiquitous Computing
courses.description: Introduces the field of ubiquitous computing, which refers to the modern era of computers embedded into everything we do, everywhere we are. From smartphones to smart homes, students will explore what makes an object or device “smart”. Topics include privacy, interfaces, location, and context-awareness. Engages students of any background in reflecting on the role of ubiquitous computing in everyday life, and thinking critically about impacts of present and future technologies.

courses.subject: INFO
courses.title: Web Systems and Services I
courses.description: Introduces technologies used to build leading-edge application systems and services on the World Wide Web. Coverage includes a selection of Web components such as mark-up and scripting languages, and server components of Web applications. Introduces Web programming using pair or small team programming activities.

courses.subject: INFO
courses.title: Web Systems and Services II
courses.description: Explores techniques used to build leading-edge application systems on the World Wide Web. Topics include Web server components of Web applications, and basic database processing. Includes Web programming using pair or small team programming activities.
courses.prerequisites: INFO 151 [Min Grade: D]

courses.subject: INFO
courses.title: Applied Data Management
courses.description: Explores technologies used to gather, organize, store, and retrieve data in various forms. Focuses on using databases and various file formats in software systems. Topics include file and database access, data munging and management, and data structures. Includes data management software development using pair or small team programming activities.
courses.prerequisites: INFO 152 [Min Grade: D]

courses.subject: INFO
courses.title: Systems Analysis I
courses.description: Study of the principles, practices, methods and tools of systems analysis. Emphasis on learning pragmatic aspects of working as a systems analyst to perform the steps of analyzing problem, value, root cause, features, use cases, user stories, and dataflow diagrams.
courses.prerequisites: INFO 101 [Min Grade: D]

courses.subject: INFO
courses.title: Data Curation
courses.description: This class explores the full range of data curation lifecycle activities, from the design of good data through metadata creation, ingest, data management, access, implementation, and reuse. It will help students develop a foundation in the curation of digital information (including data), and will enable students to understand the role and objectives of curation for organizations and projects that use data to analyze, share and provide access and re-use to collections of their digital information.
courses.prerequisites: INFO 103 [Min Grade: D]

courses.subject: INFO
courses.title: Database Management Systems
courses.description: Focuses on how to design databases for given problems, and how to use database systems effectively. Topics include database design techniques using the entity-relationship approach, techniques of translating the entity-relationship diagram into a relational schema, relational algebra, commercial query languages, and normalization techniques.
courses.prerequisites: INFO 101 [Min Grade: D] or SE 210 [Min Grade: D]

courses.subject: INFO
courses.title: Data Science Programming I
courses.description: Introduces the main tools and ideas in the data scientist’s toolbox. Focuses writing interactive and programming code for extracting, cleansing, wrangling, transforming, reshaping, and analyzing data. Covers practical tools and ideas including Linux command line, version control, git, and interactive programming. Studies various Python packages for high performance data analysis.
courses.prerequisites: INFO 153 [Min Grade: D] or CS 172 [Min Grade: D]

courses.subject: INFO
courses.title: Data Science Programming II
courses.description: Discusses the latest analytic and predictive techniques to solve real world business problems. Focuses on practice rather than theory by using existing Python libraries and tools to produce solutions. Covers practical Python implementations of the basic concepts in mathematics and statistics that are at the core of data science. Introduces Python libraries for the most common models and techniques for data analytics such as clustering, classification, regression, and decision trees.
courses.prerequisites: INFO 212 [Min Grade: D] and (STAT 201 [Min Grade: D] or MATH 311 [Min Grade: D])

courses.subject: INFO
courses.title: Social Aspects of Information Systems
courses.description: Introduces social issues involved in information systems design and use, e.g., personal computing, telecommuting, computers in education, the privacy and security of stored and transmitted information, and information ownership. Explores the interaction of high technology, employment, and class structure.

courses.subject: INFO
courses.title: Information Visualization
courses.description: Introduces the foundation and the state of the art of information visualization. Explores and reflects on the design, application, and evaluation of a diverse range of information systems. Demonstrates how a number of common types of information can be visually, intuitively and interactively represented. Provides a first-hand experience of visualizing a variety of realistic data types.

courses.subject: INFO
courses.title: Information Retrieval Systems
courses.description: The theoretical underpinnings of information retrieval are covered to give the student a solid base for further work with retrieval systems. Emphasis is given to the process of textual information for machine indexing and retrieval. Aspects of information retrieval covered include document description, query formulation, retrieval algorithms, query matching, and system evaluation.
courses.prerequisites: (INFO 153 [Min Grade: D] or CS 172 [Min Grade: D]) and INFO 102 [Min Grade: D]

courses.subject: INFO
courses.title: Human-Centered Design Process & Methods
courses.description: Introduces the student to the process of human-centered design of interactive user interfaces. Teaches some of the basic approaches to design and evaluation of interactive user interfaces. Delivers practical advice on interaction design challenges. Applies human-centered design principles in the design of the user interface to an interactive computer system.
courses.prerequisites: INFO 110 [Min Grade: D] or INFO 151 [Min Grade: D] or CS 171 [Min Grade: D] or ECE 105 [Min Grade: D] or ECE 203 [Min Grade: D]

courses.subject: INFO
courses.title: Advanced Database Management Systems
courses.description: This course will cover advanced database systems and concepts necessary in understanding modern database technologies beyond INFO 210 (Database Management Systems). Major topics include database programming in PL/SQL, including stored procedures, functions, triggers and packages, business intelligence, data warehouses, OLAP, ETL, data lake, big data architectures, and principles & practices of NoSQL databases.
courses.prerequisites: INFO 210 [Min Grade: D]

courses.subject: INFO
courses.title: Cloud Computing and Big Data
courses.description: Provides overview and insights into technologies, opportunities, and challenges related to cloud computing and big data. Covers concepts of scalable data analysis, predictive modeling, and graph analysis through specific cloud computing platforms. Introduces the components and tools in cloud computing ecosystems associated with big data solutions as well as NoSQL databases. Through hands-on instructions and assignments, students will develop working knowledge of practical tools and strategies of processing massive data sets using the map/reduce framework.
courses.prerequisites: INFO 103 [Min Grade: D] and INFO 210 [Min Grade: D] and INFO 212 [Min Grade: D]

courses.subject: INFO
courses.title: Team Process and Product
courses.description: Provides hands-on experience with working in small teams to apply processes and produce products typical of current best practices in computing and information technology organizations. Allows students to develop an integrated understanding of project life cycle phases. Examines issues of team organization and operation, problem solving, and communication.
courses.prerequisites: (INFO 153 [Min Grade: D] or CS 172 [Min Grade: D]) and INFO 200 [Min Grade: D]

courses.subject: INFO
courses.title: Exploratory Data Analytics
courses.description: In this course students learn the essential exploratory techniques for summarizing and analyzing data. The course discusses how to install and configure software necessary for a statistical programming environment. It covers practical issues in statistical computing, which includes programming in R and how to use R for effective data analysis. The course covers the plotting systems in R and some of the basic principles of constructing data graphics.
courses.prerequisites: INFO 103 [Min Grade: D] and (STAT 201 [Min Grade: D] or PBHL 211 [Min Grade: D])

courses.subject: INFO
courses.title: Systems Analysis II
courses.description: A project-oriented course that discusses software engineering and advanced techniques of requirements modeling, prototyping and software design, particularly utilizing object-oriented techniques. The course builds upon Systems Analysis I, requiring students to apply their knowledge of systems analysis tools and techniques.
courses.prerequisites: INFO 210 [Min Grade: D] and INFO 200 [Min Grade: D]

courses.subject: INFO
courses.title: Database Administration I
courses.description: Database Administration is a continuation of Database Management Systems, and includes the following: advanced ERD techniques, database management system internals and advanced elements of the SQL language, as well as stored procedures and triggers, specifically as demonstrated in the Oracle implementation.
courses.prerequisites: INFO 210 [Min Grade: D] and (CS 171 [Min Grade: D] or CS 175 [Min Grade: D] or INFO 152 [Min Grade: D] or SE 102 [Min Grade: D])

courses.subject: INFO
courses.title: Database Administration II
courses.description: Introduces the principles and practices of database administration, particularly as they apply to commercial-grade relational database management systems. The course will include, but not be limited to, installation, systems tuning, application tuning, security, user management, backup and recovery. To this end, internals of RDBMSs will be discussed, using major commercial RDBMSs as examples. Distributed database issues will also be discussed. As time permits, other advanced issues will be addressed, such as issues of object and object-relational databases.
courses.prerequisites: INFO 365 [Min Grade: D]

courses.subject: INFO
courses.title: Data Mining Applications
courses.description: Introduces students to basic data mining approaches using machine learning tools. Focuses on machine learning algorithms for information inference and knowledge discovery from data. Covers major applications in data/text/web processing, analysis and mining.
courses.prerequisites: STAT 201 [Min Grade: D] or PBHL 211 [Min Grade: D] or MATH 311 [Min Grade: D]
courses.restrictions: Cannot enroll if classification is Freshman

courses.subject: INFO
courses.title: Introduction to Information Systems Assurance
courses.description: Introduction to the problem of security for modern information systems. Provides an overview of threats, both human and computer, to the security of an organization's data and information resources. Explores how systems may be made less vulnerable and how to respond. Examines issues of personal security in an electronic world.
courses.prerequisites: INFO 200 [Min Grade: D] and CT 140 [Min Grade: D]

courses.subject: INFO
courses.title: Social and Collaborative Computing
courses.description: This course provides an introduction to the ways that computing systems support social interaction and productive collaboration. Students will learn concepts from social science theory and research and use these concepts to analyze systems and imagine novel systems designs that meet the needs of groups and organizations. Students will spend time examining, using, and participating in social and collaborative computing environments such as collaboration tools, crowdwork platforms, social media, and various online communities.
courses.prerequisites: INFO 310 [Min Grade: D] or INFO 110 [Min Grade: D]

courses.subject: INFO
courses.title: Software Project Management
courses.description: The objective of this course is to study project management in the context of software systems development. The course will cover the processes, contexts, metrics, planning and management concerns of managing projects for modern software systems.
courses.prerequisites: (INFO 200 [Min Grade: D] or SE 210 [Min Grade: D]) and (CS 172 [Min Grade: D] or CS 265 [Min Grade: D] or INFO 152 [Min Grade: D])
courses.restrictions: Can enroll if classification is Junior or Senior.

courses.subject: INFO
courses.title: Advanced Data Analytics
courses.description: Focuses on data analytic techniques that aim to understand data, discover knowledge, and learn from data. Presents the fundamentals of statistical inference and data analytic techniques in a practical approach. Provides methods on how to effectively collect data, analyze, understand data, and estimate some important quantities. Covers the key ideas in advanced functionality available in the R packages for conducting data analytics.
courses.prerequisites: INFO 332 [Min Grade: D]

courses.subject: INFO
courses.title: Social Media Data Analysis
courses.description: Explores data analytic methods for analyzing, understanding, and visualizing emerging trends on social media from social, organizational and cultural perspectives. Students will analyze various content materials and activities on social media to discern the relationship between online behavior and underlying social phenomena.
courses.prerequisites: INFO 212 [Min Grade: D] or CS 172 [Min Grade: D]

courses.subject: INFO
courses.title: Data Science Projects
courses.description: This course is a capstone course that provides an opportunity for students to apply a data science approach to solve domain problems. Students form a team and challenge a real-world project of their choices. Each team selects a domain and a data set, and then applies a data science approach to actual situations for real-world decision making. Each team is required to come up with a scientific question with a business value, perform an explorative data analysis, develop a data science model, evaluate the results, and communicate the results with audience.
courses.prerequisites: INFO 213 [Min Grade: D] and INFO 332 [Min Grade: D]

courses.subject: INFO
courses.title: Independent Study in INFO
courses.description: Self-directed within the area of study requiring intermittent consultation with a designated instructor.
courses.repeatStatus: Can be repeated multiple times for credit

courses.title: Independent Study in INFO
courses.description: Self-directed within the area of study requiring intermittent consultation with a designated instructor.

courses.subject: INFO
courses.title: Independent Study in Information Science & Systems
courses.description: Requires approval of advisor, supervising faculty member and college. BSIS majors may take a maximum of 6 credits of independent study. Any exception to this maximum must be approved in advance by the student's advisor. Independent study on a topic selected by the student. Independent study is supervised by a faculty member and guided by a plan of study developed by the student in a term prior to the term in which the independent study is pursued.
courses.repeatStatus: Can be repeated multiple times for credit

courses.title: Independent Study in INFO

courses.repeatStatus: Can be repeated multiple times for credit

courses.title: Special Topics in Information Systems
courses.description: Selected topics of interest to students in information systems. May be repeated for credit if topic varies.
courses.repeatStatus: Can be repeated multiple times for credit

courses.subject: SE
courses.title: Introduction to Software Engineering and Development
courses.description: Introduces advanced software development fundamentals including memory management, typing and scoping, datastores, software testing, and security, as well as user-centric design and user experience. This course will be taught using a specified programming language of instruction.
courses.prerequisites: CS 172 [Min Grade: C]

courses.subject: SE
courses.title: Introduction to Software Engineering and Development
courses.description: Introduces advanced software development fundamentals including memory management, typing and scoping, datastores and software testing. This course will be taught using a specified programming language of instruction.
courses.prerequisites: CS 172 [Min Grade: C]

courses.subject: SE
courses.title: Software Specification and Design I
courses.description: Study of the principles, practices, and techniques used to gather system requirements and document them in a requirements specification. Includes techniques for requirements discovery such as user interviews and prototyping. Introduces approaches for organizing and expressing software requirements in a requirements specification.
courses.prerequisites: CS 172 [Min Grade: C]

courses.subject: SE
courses.title: Software Specification and Design II
courses.description: Continues study of requirements with increasing emphasis on converting requirements into a software system design. Presents alternate approaches, techniques for evaluating specifications, specification and design tools, and use of specifications to develop system-level tests.
courses.prerequisites: SE 210 [Min Grade: C]

courses.subject: SE
courses.title: Software Architecture I
courses.description: Study of the principles and practices of object-oriented design with an emphasis on object relationships, loose coupling, and design patterns.
courses.prerequisites: CS 265 [Min Grade: C] and CS 260 [Min Grade: C] and (SE 181 [Min Grade: C] or SE 201 [Min Grade: C])

courses.subject: SE
courses.title: Software Architecture II
courses.description: Continues discussion of software architecture with a focus on micro-level architecture including patterns, frameworks, and component-based software engineering, and commercial off-the-shelf software.
courses.prerequisites: SE 310 [Min Grade: C]

courses.subject: SE
courses.title: Software Verification and Validation
courses.description: Presents theory and practice of software testing. Covers structural testing including such topics as path testing, dataflow testing, logic based testing, syntax testing, program slicing, mutation testing, fault injection, program perturbation, and testing tools. Discusses techniques for test construction and test suite evaluation, and validation against requirements and design models. Also covers methods of inspection and review at various phases of the software lifecycle.
courses.prerequisites: CS 260 [Min Grade: C] and (SE 181 [Min Grade: C] or SE 201 [Min Grade: C])

courses.subject: SE
courses.title: Software Evolution
courses.description: Covers issues related to change in software systems. Addresses principles and techniques of corrective software maintenance, software enhancements, and software product family. Introduces students to issues of change in large software systems including configuration control, change and product management.
courses.prerequisites: CS 260 [Min Grade: C]

courses.subject: SE
courses.title: Open Source Software Engineering
courses.description: Explores tools, techniques, process, and culture of free and open source software (FOSS) projects. Addresses open source project evaluation, business models, and FOSS as a source of software engineering innovation. Includes student participation in an existing humanitarian FOSS project. Introduces concepts of computing for social good.
courses.prerequisites: CS 260 [Min Grade: C]

courses.description: Self-directed within the area of study requiring intermittent consultation with a designated instructor.
courses.repeatStatus: Can be repeated multiple times for credit

courses.subject: CIVC
courses.title: Foundations of Civic Engagement
courses.description: This course is designed to help students develop skills as active participants in a pluralistic democratic society through direct service, education, and reflection opportunities. It will cover key concepts and frameworks for understanding civic engagement, including: models of civic life through American history; critiques of philanthropy, volunteerism, community service, public service, and political activism; and university-community relations.

courses.subject: CIVC
courses.title: Introduction to Civic Engagement
courses.description: In this course, students will explore what it means to be a responsible, socially-conscious citizen of Philadelphia and the world. Students will explore the broad definition of civic engagement and critically examine concepts of identity, community, and systems to better understand social issues and build a foundation for making social change through civic engagement. As a community-engaged learning course, students will combine classroom learning with volunteerism and other interactions with community. Throughout the course, students will participate in reflective activities to tie together their learning and engagement and provide tools to advance their knowledge and practice beyond the course.

courses.subject: CIVC
courses.title: Active Citizenship and Community-Based Learning
courses.description: By exploring the conceptions of active citizenship and taking part in civic engagement activities, this course will examine issues regarding community-based learning experiences for today's university students.
courses.prerequisites: CIVC 100 [Min Grade: D]

courses.subject: CIVC
courses.title: Civic Engagement Leadership
courses.description: This course provides experiential learning in community settings as students observe, define, analyze, and practice leadership skills.
courses.prerequisites: CIVC 100 [Min Grade: D]

courses.subject: CIVC
courses.title: University-Community Partnerships
courses.description: This course will examine the university as a social institution and community actor.
courses.prerequisites: CIVC 100 [Min Grade: D]

courses.subject: CIVC
courses.title: Capstone Project in Civic Engagement
courses.description: Under faculty supervision, students plan and execute a term project that integrates the academic and community-based knowledge acquired in their curriculum. Students define an issue and set learning objectives relevant to the project, develop a plan for implementation, and complete the term project.

courses.subject: AE
courses.title: Introduction to HVAC
courses.description: This course includes a review of thermodynamics, moist air properties and processes, basic heat transfer, solar radiation, heating and cooling losses and load calculation, types of air conditioning systems, infiltration and ventilation, air motion and distribution.
courses.prerequisites: (CAEE 202 [Min Grade: D] and CAEE 203 [Min Grade: D]) or ENGR 210 [Min Grade: D] or CHE 206 [Min Grade: D]
courses.restrictions: Cannot enroll if classification is Freshman

courses.subject: AE
courses.title: Architectural Illumination and Electrical Systems
courses.description: This course covers building electrical systems, including power demand, distribution and control; building illumination techniques, including lighting demand, layout and energy analysis.
courses.prerequisites: (CAEE 202 [Min Grade: D] and PHYS 102 [Min Grade: D]) or ENGR 210 [Min Grade: D] or CHE 206 [Min Grade: D]
courses.restrictions: Cannot enroll if classification is Freshman

courses.subject: AE
courses.title: Architectural Engineering Design I
courses.description: This course leads students through the comprehensive building design process. Using a prototype of a moderately sized building, students work in teams to develop the building’s program, meet architectural goals, and organize and design components of the structural system. Working for a fictitious client, the teams are faced with unique challenges which will need to be addressed through a whole-building design approach. The teams present their design solutions with a thorough Design Development narrative, professional diagrams, and a verbal presentation to a panel of industry professionals.
courses.prerequisites: ARCH 192 [Min Grade: D] and MEM 202 [Min Grade: D]
courses.restrictions: Cannot enroll if classification is Freshman

courses.subject: AE
courses.title: Architectural Engineering Design II
courses.description: In this course, students will design the mechanical, electrical, and plumbing systems for a mid-sized building located in different climate zones in the United States. The students integrate their design project from the previous term, continuing the work they began in AE390, through a whole-building design approach. The class is organized as a team-based project-based learning pedagogy in which teams present their design solutions with a thorough Design Development narrative, professional diagrams, and a verbal presentation to the class and a jury of experts.
courses.prerequisites: AE 390 [Min Grade: D] and AE 220 [Min Grade: D] and AE 340 [Min Grade: D]
courses.restrictions: Cannot enroll if classification is Freshman

courses.subject: AE
courses.title: Intelligent Buildings
courses.description: An overview of the present and future role of Information Technology in the construction industry with emphasis on the computer tools used throughout the building life cycle by all stakeholders, primarily Building Information Modeling (BIM) and the role of networked-linked sensors and actuators.

courses.subject: AE
courses.title: Control Systems for HVAC
courses.description: This course introduces basic control concepts with applications to HVAC systems; direct digital control, control loops; system modeling; transfer functions; selecting and locating sensors and actuators; design and tuning control algorithms; design and programming of HVAC control systems.
courses.prerequisites: AE 220 [Min Grade: D] or MEM 413 [Min Grade: D]

courses.subject: AE
courses.title: Responsive Urban Environments
courses.description: This is a real-time Global Classroom that meets simultaneously in Philadelphia and Milan, Italy. The Responsive Urban Environment (RUE)looks at the city through the lens of ecosystem management. RUE considers the city as a complex network of interrelated systems that rely on each other to maintain system balance. RUE helps students understand the close relationship between the engineering design choices that take place at the scale of the building and neighborhood to the environmental impacts that occur at the wider scale of the urban level.

courses.subject: AE
courses.title: Bio-inspired Design
courses.description: This course introduces bio-informed sciences into engineering design to help students develop engineering strategies for the built environment to promote human health and wellbeing. Topics covered include neuroscience, photobiology, biomimicry, biophilia, and chronobiology.

courses.subject: AE
courses.title: Building Envelope Systems
courses.description: Science and engineering fundamentals in analysis and design of building envelopes and wall systems. Architectural, structural, and environmental (thermal and moisture) concerns; features of selected cladding systems; air and moisture leakage, thermal deficiency, structural distress and premature deterioration; building envelop construction, condition evaluation, maintenance and retrofit.
courses.prerequisites: AE 391 [Min Grade: C] or CIVE 303 [Min Grade: C]
courses.restrictions: Can enroll if major is AE or major is CIVE.

courses.subject: AE
courses.title: Data Acquisition and Analytics in Built Environment
courses.description: Introduce concepts on data acquisition, data storage, and data analytics in the context of the built environment. Students will be learning sensor technology and database design and operation in buildings, as well as novel concepts of leveraging data science for engineering challenges.

courses.subject: AE
courses.title: Independent Study in Architectural Engineering
courses.description: Independent study on a topic selected by the student. Independent study is supervised by a faculty member and guided by a plan of study.
courses.repeatStatus: Can be repeated multiple times for credit

courses.subject: BET
courses.title: Healthcare Technology
courses.description: An overview of medical equipment used in hospitals and other medical environments to diagnose and treat patients. Sensors and physiological signals will be explained. Equipment found in various hospital departments and medical specialties will also be discussed. Patient safety and regulations will be emphasized.
courses.prerequisites: EET 201 [Min Grade: D] and EET 202 [Min Grade: D]

courses.subject: BET
courses.title: Biomedical Electronics
courses.description: This course is an introduction to the fundamentals of analog electronics with an emphasis on biomedical applications. Students will be introduced to solid state devices including diodes, transistors, operational amplifiers, oscillators, and mixers and their use in power supplies, amplifiers and active filters.
courses.prerequisites: EET 201 [Min Grade: D] and EET 202 [Min Grade: D]

courses.subject: BET
courses.title: Medical Imaging Systems
courses.description: The fundamentals of medical imaging equipment will be explored. The principles of x-ray, computed tomography, ultrasonic, and magnetic resonance imaging systems will be discussed. Focus will be on principles of operation, applications, safety, and quality.
courses.prerequisites: BET 301 [Min Grade: D]

courses.subject: BET
courses.title: Clinical Laboratory Equipment
courses.description: Clinical laboratory instrumentation and automation is described with emphasis on the demands of clinicians for diagnostic information. Special attention is given to reliability, ease of training, and cost effectiveness.
courses.prerequisites: EET 201 [Min Grade: D] and EET 202 [Min Grade: D] and BET 301 [Min Grade: D]

courses.subject: BET
courses.title: Applied Biomedical Instrumentation
courses.description: The course introduces students to the engineering design process and provides design experience through hands-on design and implementation of biomedical instruments. Using a generalized step-by-step approach that consists of (1) understanding the physiological sources, (2) selecting appropriate transducers, (3) designing analog processing electronics, and (4) implementing digital signal processing, student will gain extensible knowledge and skills to design and implement various biomedical instruments.
courses.prerequisites: EET 201 [Min Grade: D] and EET 202 [Min Grade: D] and BET 301 [Min Grade: D] and BMES 391 [Min Grade: D]

courses.subject: BET
courses.title: Independent Study in Biomedical Engineering Tech
courses.description: Self-directed within the area of study requiring intermittent consultation with a designated instructor.
courses.repeatStatus: Can be repeated multiple times for credit

courses.subject: CHE
courses.title: Material and Energy Balances I
courses.description: Covers elementary principles of chemical engineering, use of stoichiometry and material and energy balances to analyze chemical processing operations, and application to specific commercial processes.
courses.prerequisites: CHEM 102 [Min Grade: D] and MATH 122 [Min Grade: D]

courses.subject: CHE
courses.title: Material and Energy Balances II
courses.description: Covers application of material and energy balances to analyze chemical processing operations, with application to both small-scale and commercial processes. Emphasis is on simultaneous solution of material and energy balances and on time-dependent analysis.
courses.prerequisites: CHE 211 [Min Grade: D] and CHE 220 [Min Grade: D]

courses.subject: CHE
courses.title: Computational Methods in Chemical Engineering I
courses.description: Introduces computational approaches and software applied to solve problems in chemical engineering. Software includes spreadsheet programs (Excel), high level computing languages (MATLAB), and chemical process simulation tools (Aspen, HYSYS).
courses.prerequisites: ENGR 131 [Min Grade: D] or ENGR 132 [Min Grade: D]

courses.subject: CHE
courses.title: Chemical Engineering Thermodynamics I
courses.description: First and second laws of thermodynamics, use of state functions to solve macroscopic problems, distinction between solving ideal gas and real fluid problems. An introduction to phase equilibrium and mixtures. Concepts of fugacity and activity as measures of nonideality.
courses.prerequisites: MATH 200 [Min Grade: D] and CHE 211 [Min Grade: D] and CHE 220 [Min Grade: D]

courses.subject: CHE
courses.title: Computational Methods in Chemical Engineering II
courses.description: This course introduces computational approaches and software applied to solve problems in chemical engineering. The course includes finite element software for solving differential equations (COMSOL Multiphysics) and computer programming.
courses.prerequisites: CHE 341 [Min Grade: D] and CHE 220 [Min Grade: D]

courses.subject: CHE
courses.title: Chemical Engineering Thermodynamics II
courses.description: Covers mixture thermodynamics, multi-component, multi-phase equilibrium calculations, and chemical equilibrium calculations for real fluids.
courses.prerequisites: CHE 230 [Min Grade: D]

courses.subject: CHE
courses.title: Separation Processes
courses.description: Covers application of thermodynamics and equilibrium stage concepts to separation unit operations in chemical processing.
courses.prerequisites: CHE 330 [Min Grade: D] and CHE 343 [Min Grade: D]

courses.subject: CHE
courses.title: Fluid Mechanics
courses.description: Introduces, within the context of processes, transport phenomena, fluid flow, momentum transport, skin friction, drag, and piping networks.
courses.prerequisites: CHE 212 [Min Grade: D] and CHE 230 [Min Grade: D] and MATH 210 [Min Grade: D]

courses.subject: CHE
courses.title: Heat Transfer
courses.description: Covers, as a continuation of transport phenomena and within the context of processes, transfer of energy by conduction, convection, and radiation and design of heat exchangers.
courses.prerequisites: CHE 341 [Min Grade: D]

courses.subject: CHE
courses.title: Mass Transfer
courses.description: Covers, within the context of processes previously introduced, mass transfer in mixtures; diffusion, convection, and continuation of transport phenomena; component separation in continuous contactors; gas absorption; liquid-liquid extraction; and simultaneous heat and mass transfer.
courses.prerequisites: CHE 341 [Min Grade: D]

courses.subject: CHE
courses.title: Transport Phenomena in Bioengineering Processes
courses.description: Covers gas-liquid mass transfer in microbial systems, mass transfer in cells and biofilms, membrane transport, fluid mechanics of fermentation broth, power consumption in agitated vessels, heat transfer, and scale-up of mass transfer equipment.
courses.prerequisites: (CHE 343 [Min Grade: D] or CHE 304 [Min Grade: D]) and (CHE 341 [Min Grade: D] or CHE 302 [Min Grade: D])

courses.subject: CHE
courses.title: Statistics and Design of Experiments
courses.description: Provides statistical treatment of engineering data including application of statistical techniques to process model formulation, statistical designs of engineering experiments, and analysis of probabilistic systems.
courses.prerequisites: MATH 210 [Min Grade: D] or ENGR 232 [Min Grade: D] or MATH 262 [Min Grade: D]

courses.subject: CHE
courses.title: Chemical Engineering Laboratory I
courses.description: Offers laboratory experience in chemical engineering processes, requiring both experimental design and analysis.
courses.prerequisites: CHE 341 [Min Grade: D] and CHE 330 [Min Grade: D]

courses.subject: CHE
courses.title: Chemical Engineering Laboratory II
courses.description: Offers laboratory experience in chemical engineering processes, requiring both experimental design and analysis.
courses.prerequisites: CHE 343 [Min Grade: D] and CHE 331 [Min Grade: D]

courses.subject: CHE
courses.title: BioProcess Principles
courses.description: This course is concerned with manufacturing processes involving biological substances. Students gain detailed knowledge in the design and operation of bioreactors and learn about biomolecules produces therein. Specific topics covered include: Cells (type, organization, function and growth); Protein and Enzymes; Bioreactor Process Principles (active vs. passive immobilization, fermentation and scale-up, recovery and purification); Special consideration for animal and plant cell cultures.
courses.prerequisites: CHE 211 [Min Grade: D] or CHE 201 [Min Grade: D]

courses.subject: CHE
courses.title: Chemical Kinetics and Reactor Design
courses.description: Covers isothermal and non-isothermal reactor design, series and parallel reactions, and heterogeneous catalysis.
courses.prerequisites: CHE 330 [Min Grade: D] and CHE 342 [Min Grade: D] and CHE 343 [Min Grade: D]

courses.subject: CHE
courses.title: Bioprocess Unit Operations
courses.description: Covers separation processes applicable to bio-systems, including liquid-liquid extractions, membrane separations, chromatographic separations, filtration, and centrifugation.
courses.prerequisites: CHE 305 [Min Grade: D] or CHE 331 [Min Grade: D]

courses.subject: CHE
courses.title: Engineering Economics and Professional Practice
courses.description: Provides techniques for making engineering project decisions. Topics include the time value of money, key decision criteria, risk analysis, and ethical considerations and consequences of business decisions.
courses.prerequisites: CHE 211 [Min Grade: D] and CHE 220 [Min Grade: D]

courses.subject: CHE
courses.title: Integrated Case Studies in Chemical Engineering
courses.description: This course reviews selected cases (market, processes, equipment sets and incidents) from chemical engineering practice whose analysis requires integration of concepts from previous Chemical Engineering courses such as mass and energy transport, thermodynamics, separations and reaction engineering.
courses.prerequisites: CHE 342 [Min Grade: D] and CHE 343 [Min Grade: D]

courses.subject: CHE
courses.title: The Brewing Process
courses.description: This course will focus on the critical process steps which make up the brewing process on any scale with special attention to the chemistry and biochemistry of the involved process steps. The lecture material includes the brewing process steps from raw materials to fill/finish including: raw materials, malting, mashing, lautering, boiling, hopping, fermentation, clarification (filtration/centrifugation/flocculation), and fill/finish, as well as a discussion of the fundamentals, impurities chemistry, health concerns and practical knowledge.
courses.prerequisites: CHEM 242 [Min Grade: D]

courses.subject: CHE
courses.title: Solutions to Climate Change
courses.description: Climate change will likely be the most important challenge of our time. Drawdown is the theoretical point in the future when greenhouse gas concentrations in the atmosphere peak and then begin to decline, reversing the trend of global warming. Can we get there? How? We will examine the potential impacts of dozens of top solutions to understand where our actions have the most leverage. Solutions range from technical (green energy, buildings, and transportation) to non-technical (food choices and education). The best solutions not only mitigate global warming but also lead to economic benefits and a more just and equitable society.

courses.subject: CHE
courses.title: Process Systems Engineering
courses.description: Covers the application of automatic control theory to chemical processes within the context of processes previously introduced.
courses.prerequisites: (CHE 201 [Min Grade: D] or CHE 211 [Min Grade: D]) and (CHE 202 [Min Grade: D] or CHE 212 [Min Grade: D]) and CHE 303 [Min Grade: D]
courses.restrictions: Cannot enroll if classification is Freshman

courses.subject: CHE
courses.title: Introduction to Sustainable Engineering
courses.description: This course introduces students to sustainability in an engineering context. Sustainable engineering encompasses the relationships between technology, society, the environment, and economic prosperity. A variety of systematic approaches will be used for multivariable design and analysis of the sustainability of engineering systems.
courses.restrictions: Can enroll if classification is Junior or Senior.

courses.subject: CHE
courses.title: Fundamentals of Solar Cells
courses.description: This course focuses on the fundamentals of solar cells. It will cover semiconductor materials, basic semiconductor physics, optical and electronic phenomena, and case studies of crystalline silicon, thin film, and nanostructured photovoltaics.
courses.prerequisites: MATH 200 [Min Grade: D] and CHEM 102 [Min Grade: D] and PHYS 102 [Min Grade: D]

courses.subject: CHE
courses.title: Electrochemical Engineering
courses.description: This course introduces principles and application of electrochemical equilibria, kinetics, and transport processes.
courses.prerequisites: CHE 330 [Min Grade: D] and CHE 343 [Min Grade: D]

courses.subject: CHE
courses.title: Introduction to Rheology
courses.description: Introduces the concepts of how science defines and conceptualizes the behavior of “real” fluids. Covers concepts such as how to characterize, quantify, and simulate non-Newtonian behavior in real fluids.
courses.prerequisites: CHE 341 [Min Grade: D] or CHE 302 [Min Grade: D]

courses.subject: CHE
courses.title: Polymer Process Technology
courses.description: Covers chemistry of chain and stepwise polymerization, industrial reactor systems, polymer melt rheology, processing of thermoplastic resins, and plastics properties.
courses.restrictions: Can enroll if classification is Junior or Senior.

courses.subject: CHE
courses.title: Chemical Engineering Laboratory III
courses.description: Offers laboratory experience in chemical engineering processes, requiring both experimental design and analysis.
courses.prerequisites: CHE 362 [Min Grade: D] (Can be taken Concurrently)

courses.subject: CHE
courses.title: Biochemical Engineering
courses.description: Introduces underlying biological and engineering principles in an integrate fashion for biopharmaceutical production systems.
courses.restrictions: Can enroll if major is BME or major is CHE and classification is Junior or Senior.

courses.subject: CHE
courses.title: Principles of Colloid Science
courses.description: This course focuses on fundamental principles of colloid science from a biological perspective. It will cover surface active agents, thermodynamics of self-assembly of surfactants, surface chemistry and physics of monolayers and bilayers, microstructures and phase behavior, specific biological colloids (micelles, liposomes, and lipoproteins), and colloidal stability.
courses.prerequisites: BIO 141 [Min Grade: C] or BIO 122 [Min Grade: C]
courses.restrictions: Can enroll if classification is Junior or Senior.

courses.subject: CHE
courses.title: Process Dynamics and Control
courses.description: Covers the application of automatic control theory to chemical processes within the context of processes.
courses.prerequisites: MATH 210 [Min Grade: D] and CHE 212 [Min Grade: D]

courses.subject: CHE
courses.title: Chemical Process Safety
courses.description: Covers selected topics such as safeguarding systems, fault trees, risk analysis, explosions, fires, and process safety.
courses.prerequisites: CHE 472 [Min Grade: D]

courses.subject: CHE
courses.title: Process Design I
courses.description: Within the context of previously introduced processes, covers economic feasibility of projects and optimization of equipment and production in the design of process plants.
courses.prerequisites: CHE 331 [Min Grade: D], CHE 362 [Min Grade: D] (Can be taken Concurrently) and CHE 371 [Min Grade: D] and CHE 372 [Min Grade: D]

courses.subject: CHE
courses.title: Process Design II
courses.description: Within the context of previously introduced processes, covers execution of feasibility study and preliminary design of process plants.
courses.prerequisites: CHE 471 [Min Grade: D]

courses.subject: CHE
courses.title: Process Design III
courses.description: Within the context of previously introduced processes, covers completion of feasibility study and preliminary design of process plants.
courses.prerequisites: CHE 472 [Min Grade: D]

courses.subject: CHE
courses.title: Senior Thesis Research
courses.description: This course teaches students the ability to structure and write a thesis and defend their research.
courses.prerequisites: CHE I499 [Min Grade: D]

courses.subject: CHE
courses.title: Independent Study in Chemical Engineering
courses.description: Self-directed within the area of study requiring intermittent consultation with a designated instructor.
courses.repeatStatus: Can be repeated multiple times for credit

courses.title: Independent Study in Chemical Engineering

courses.subject: CHE
courses.title: Special Topics in CHE
courses.description: Topics decided upon by faculty will vary within the area of study.
courses.repeatStatus: Can be repeated multiple times for credit
courses.restrictions: Cannot enroll if classification is Freshman

courses.subject: CAE
courses.title: Senior Design Project I
courses.description: Introduces the design process, including information retrieval, problem definition, proposal writing, patents, and design notebooks. Includes presentations on problem areas by experts from industry, government, and education.
courses.prerequisites: (CIVE 330 [Min Grade: D] and CIVE 303 [Min Grade: D]) or (AE 391 [Min Grade: D] and CIVE 303 [Min Grade: D]) or (CIVE 330 [Min Grade: D] and CIVE 312 [Min Grade: D]) or (CIVE 303 [Min Grade: D] and CIVE 312 [Min Grade: D]) or (AE 391 [Min Grade: D] and CIVE 330 [Min Grade: D])
courses.restrictions: Can enroll if classification is Senior.

courses.subject: CAE
courses.title: Senior Design Project II
courses.description: Continues CAE 491. Requires written and oral progress reports.
courses.prerequisites: CAE 491 [Min Grade: D]

courses.subject: CAE
courses.title: Senior Design Project III
courses.description: Continues CAE 492. Requires written and oral final reports, including oral presentations by each design team at a formal Design Conference open to the public and conducted in the style of a professional conference.
courses.prerequisites: CAE 492 [Min Grade: D]
courses.restrictions: Cannot enroll if classification is Freshman

courses.subject: CIVE
courses.title: Engineering Economic Analysis
courses.description: Techniques for project decisions: benefit cost and present worth analysis, rate of return, capital budgeting, risk analysis, environmental impact, and depreciation.
courses.restrictions: Cannot enroll if classification is Freshman

courses.subject: CIVE
courses.title: Construction Materials
courses.description: Construction Materials.
courses.prerequisites: MEM 202 [Min Grade: D] and (ENGR 220 [Min Grade: D] or MATE 220 [Min Grade: D])

courses.subject: CIVE
courses.title: Structural Analysis I
courses.description: Covers analysis of statically determinate structures: equilibrium, compatibility, boundary conditions, complimentary and virtual work, energy theorems, reactions, member forces and deflection of trusses, beams and frames, and influence lines. The laboratory portion will make use of structural analysis computer programs to construct analytical models of various structural systems. Calculate reactions and deflections of statically determinate and indeterminate structures and check reliability of results.
courses.prerequisites: CIVE 250 [Min Grade: D] and MEM 230 [Min Grade: D]
courses.restrictions: Cannot enroll if classification is Freshman

courses.subject: CIVE
courses.title: Structural Design I
courses.description: This course will provide a general overview of engineering design (20%) and then a specific treatment of the structural design process (80%). The key topics to be covered include the determination of system-level loads/demands, the estimation of element-level demands and demand envelops, and the sizing of beams and columns constructed of both reinforced concrete and structural steel.
courses.prerequisites: CIVE 302 [Min Grade: D]
courses.restrictions: Cannot enroll if classification is Freshman

courses.subject: CIVE
courses.title: Soil Mechanics I
courses.description: Overview of geotechnical engineering; principles and practices. Exploration methods and soil profile preparation. Index properties used in engineering and agricultural classification systems. Description and modification of three phase particulate and void descriptions and modification. Laminar liquids flow as per dArcy’s law.
courses.prerequisites: (CAEE 212 [Min Grade: D] or GEO 101 [Min Grade: D]) and CIVE 320 [Min Grade: D]

courses.subject: CIVE
courses.title: Soil Mechanics II
courses.description: This course covers stress-strain and stability behavior of porous particulate soil. Effective stress and laminar flow are combined in one-dimensional consolidation. Stress distribution from applied loads and the resulting deformation are addressed in elastic and plastic equilibrium stages. Failure theory and measurement of strength properties are included, along with basic application to slopes, retaining structures, and both shallow and deep foundations.
courses.prerequisites: MEM 230 [Min Grade: D] and CIVE 250 [Min Grade: D] and CIVE 312 [Min Grade: D]

courses.subject: CIVE
courses.title: Introduction to Fluid Flow
courses.description: Covers fundamentals of fluid flow, fluid properties, hydrostatic forces, kinematics of flow, the Bernoulli equation, linear momentum, dimensional analysis, Froude and Reynolds similarity and hydraulic models and an introduction to pipe flows and friction.
courses.prerequisites: MEM 210 [Min Grade: D] or ENGR 210 [Min Grade: D]

courses.subject: CIVE
courses.title: Hydraulics
courses.description: Applications of the principles of fluid mechanics to the design and analysis of hydraulic structures and systems. Principles of confined flow, pipe networks, open channel flow, channel design, hydraulic modeling, and introduction to unsteady flow.
courses.prerequisites: CIVE 320 [Min Grade: D]

courses.subject: CIVE
courses.title: Structural Material Behavior
courses.description: Study of deformation, fracture and fatigue of structural materials used in infrastructure. Includes basic failure modes, yielding and plasticity, and fracture mechanics. Emphasis on analytical and predictive methods that designers use to avoid failure. Metals, ceramic and composites are considered, as is time-dependent behavior.
courses.prerequisites: MEM 230 [Min Grade: D] and CIVE 250 [Min Grade: D] and (MATH 201 [Min Grade: D] or MATH 261 [Min Grade: D] or CAEE 231 [Min Grade: D] or ENGR 231 [Min Grade: D])
courses.restrictions: Cannot enroll if classification is Freshman

courses.subject: CIVE
courses.title: Structural Analysis II
courses.description: This course expounds on CIVE 302 (analysis of determinate structures) by introducing problems for which statics alone cannot solve for the unknown reactions and forces. This course covers the analysis of statically indeterminate structures: force methods for trusses, beams and frames, slope-deflection and equilibrium methods, moment distribution, stiffness matrices of truss and beam elements, and stiffness matrix method of analysis.
courses.prerequisites: CIVE 303 [Min Grade: C]
courses.restrictions: Can enroll if classification is Senior.

courses.subject: CIVE
courses.title: Structural Design II
courses.description: Covers principles of design of reinforced concrete structural systems, including beams, slabs, columns, and footings.
courses.prerequisites: CIVE 400 [Min Grade: D]
courses.restrictions: Cannot enroll if classification is Freshman

courses.subject: CIVE
courses.title: Structural Design III
courses.description: Covers elastic and plastic design of structural steel members, including beams, columns, tension members, beam columns, and plate girders; design of welded and high-strength bolted connections; and design of steel trusses, bridges, and buildings.
courses.prerequisites: CIVE 400 [Min Grade: D]
courses.restrictions: Cannot enroll if classification is Freshman

courses.subject: CIVE
courses.title: Advanced Steel Design
courses.description: Covers a variety of special topics in steel design including (i) plate girders, (ii) composite beams, (iii) frame analysis and design (i.e., summation of P concept and direct analysis method), (iv) special connection detailing (e.g., moment connections and gusset plates), (v) beam, column, and frame bracing, (vi) fatigue and fracture.
courses.prerequisites: CIVE 402 [Min Grade: D]

courses.subject: CIVE
courses.title: Geotechnical Site Investigation
courses.description: This course will cover best practices for the geotechnical characterization of subsurface conditions required for successful planning, design, construction, and operation of civil infrastructure. The course provides historical, theoretical, experimental, and empirical development of different in-situ tests in geotechnical engineering. Practical applications and limitations of field-testing devices will be studied. Interpretation of test results and measurements for geotechnical site characterization will be discussed.
courses.prerequisites: CIVE 312 [Min Grade: D]
courses.restrictions: Cannot enroll if classification is Freshman

courses.subject: CIVE
courses.title: Natural Hazards and Infrastructure
courses.description: Overview of natural hazards in the form of landslides, earthquakes, windstorms, tsunamis, hurricanes, floods, scour, subsidence, tornadoes, wildfires, etc. Covers processes and risk to civil infrastructure through case histories and post-disaster reconnaissance to improve our understanding of these hazards and how to help us mitigate the risk posed by these natural hazards.
courses.prerequisites: CAEE 212 [Min Grade: D]

courses.subject: CIVE
courses.title: Foundation Engineering
courses.description: Engineering properties of soils focused on soil shear strength and compressibility in determining the bearing capacity and settlement of shallow and deep foundations in sands, clays, and layered geotechnical profiles.
courses.prerequisites: CIVE 315 [Min Grade: C]
courses.restrictions: Cannot enroll if classification is Freshman

courses.subject: CIVE
courses.title: Lateral Earth Pressures and Retaining Structures
courses.description: In this course, students will learn classical and modern lateral earth pressure theories, effects of wall friction and external loads (including earthquakes). Geotechnical design, including computer applications, of retaining structures including rigid and flexible retaining walls; Deadman anchors, sheet pile walls, mechanically stabilized soil reinforcement systems, and excavation bracing.
courses.prerequisites: CIVE 315 [Min Grade: C]
courses.restrictions: Cannot enroll if classification is Freshman

courses.subject: CIVE
courses.title: Engineering Ground Improvement
courses.description: This course covers the improvement of soil properties to meet project requirements, including surface and in situ technologies: compaction, densification, precompression, stabilization with admixtures, grouting and dewatering.
courses.prerequisites: CIVE 315 [Min Grade: C]
courses.restrictions: Cannot enroll if classification is Freshman

courses.subject: CIVE
courses.title: Hydrology
courses.description: Covers the relationship between precipitation and runoff, unit hydrographs, flood routing, and water supply principles and applications.
courses.prerequisites: CAEE 212 [Min Grade: D] and CIVE 320 [Min Grade: D]
courses.restrictions: Cannot enroll if classification is Freshman

courses.subject: CIVE
courses.title: Hydrology-Ground Water
courses.description: Covers geologic and hydrologic occurrence of groundwater, underground flow, and groundwater supply. Winter.
courses.prerequisites: CIVE 330 [Min Grade: D]
courses.restrictions: Cannot enroll if classification is Freshman

courses.subject: CIVE
courses.title: Transportation Engineering
courses.description: This course will introduce basic knowledge, mathematical models, and solution tools to various highway traffic problems. Topics that will be covered include components in highway systems (driver, vehicle, road, and intersection), probability and statistics for transportation engineers, queuing theory, traffic flow basics, highway capacity and level of service, traffic control, traffic safety, and emerging transportation technologies.

courses.subject: CIVE
courses.title: Transportation System Planning
courses.description: This course introduces topics and concepts of transportation planning and methods to analyze the impacts of transportation systems on society. The core of this course is travel demand modeling, which employs mathematical models (Don’t be scared by the name; You will learn how simple some of them are after taking this course) to predict the distribution of travel demand across time and space. The course will also cover methods and case studies on transportation system impact analysis, including benefit-cost analysis and equity impact analysis. Emerging topics such as planning for new transportation technologies, the use of artificial intelligence and big data analytics in transportation planning will also be discussed.
courses.prerequisites: CIVE 450 [Min Grade: D]

courses.subject: CIVE
courses.title: Traffic Flow Theory
courses.description: This course introduces topics and concepts of traffic flow theory and their applications, including models (single vehicle dynamics, car following models, lane-change models, etc.), data (sensing, data processing, model calibration and validation), and applications (microscopic traffic simulation, connected and automated vehicles).
courses.prerequisites: CIVE 450 [Min Grade: D]

courses.subject: CIVE
courses.title: Seminar I
courses.description: Covers professional development and ethics. Requires preparation of a technical paper. It is anticipated that each student will attend a weekly one (1) hour seminar and work a minimum of two (2) hours per week on research in the development of their technical paper.
courses.restrictions: Can enroll if classification is Junior or Senior.

courses.subject: CIVE
courses.title: Seminar II
courses.description: Requires developing and delivering a presentation on a technical paper. Students are expected to attend a minimum of 50% of the scheduled class meetings.
courses.prerequisites: CIVE 477 [Min Grade: D]
courses.restrictions: Can enroll if classification is Junior or Senior.

courses.subject: CAEE
courses.title: Introduction to Civil, Architectural & Environmental Engineering
courses.description: This course introduces the planning, design, construction, operation, maintenance and documentation of engineering projects that are in unique social, topographic, environmental and geologic settings. The scope and principles of Civil, Architectural and Environmental engineering practice are each presented as well as the relationships between the three disciplines. The concepts are illustrated through laboratory projects, case studies, field trips and field measurement exercises. The course also addresses professional ethics, practice and licensure.

courses.subject: CAEE
courses.title: System Balances and Design in CAEE
courses.description: Based on fundamental science and mathematics preparation, this course for students in Civil, Architectural and Environmental Engineering covers delineation of system boundaries, analysis of mass, energy and force balances that support system integration; life cycle and uncertainty analysis; and formulation of problem solutions using these balances.
courses.prerequisites: MATH 122 [Min Grade: D]

courses.subject: CAEE
courses.title: Geologic Principles for Infrastructure & Environmental Engineering
courses.description: This course focuses on geological principles and their relationships to engineering properties and behavior of soil and rock materials. Topics include formation of minerals, igneous, sedimentary, and metamorphic rocks, plate tectonics, structural geology, rock mechanics, landforms and geological hazards. Labs focus on mineral and rock identification, map skills, and rock mechanics.
courses.prerequisites: MATE 220 [Min Grade: D] or ENGR 220 [Min Grade: D]

courses.subject: CAEE
courses.title: Linear Engineering Systems
courses.description: Provides an overview of systems and modeling; specifically using linear algebra as the model. Specific emphasis will be placed on developing models of engineering systems and the use of computational tools for solutions to the problems. The focus of the lab will be the use of MATLAB for the solution of contemporary engineering problems.
courses.prerequisites: MATH 122 [Min Grade: D]

courses.subject: CAEE
courses.title: Dynamic Engineering Systems
courses.description: Provides an overview of dynamic systems and modeling; specifically using differential equations as the model. Specific emphasis will be placed on developing models of engineering systems and the use of computational tools for solutions to the problems. The focus of the lab will be the use of MATLAB for the solution of contemporary engineering problems. Laplace transforms will be introduced as a means to study systems and solutions to differential equations. Basic control laws will also be introduced.
courses.prerequisites: CAEE 231 [Min Grade: D] or ENGR 231 [Min Grade: D]

courses.subject: CAEE
courses.title: Community-Based Design
courses.description: This course evaluates the weight of evidence for community-based design practices as related to peacebuilding, conflict management and sustainable development. A case-study-based approach will enable students to study participatory theory, informed design and adaptive management.

courses.subject: CAEE
courses.title: Statistical Analysis of Engineering Systems
courses.description: This class covers probability and statistics with applications to civil, architectural, and environmental engineering. Students will learn probability theory, distributions of random variables, and statistical hypothesis testing.

courses.subject: CAEE
courses.title: Independent Study in Civil, Architecture & Environmental Engineering
courses.description: Self-directed within the area of study requiring intermittent consultation with a designated instructor.
courses.repeatStatus: Can be repeated multiple times for credit
