courses.title: Special Topics in INDE
courses.description: Topics decided upon by faculty will vary within the area of study.
courses.repeatStatus: Can be repeated multiple times for credit
courses.restrictions: Cannot enroll if classification is Freshman

courses.subject: INDE
courses.title: Special Topics in INDE
courses.description: Topics decided upon by faculty will vary within the area of study.
courses.repeatStatus: Can be repeated multiple times for credit

courses.subject: MET
courses.title: Graphical Communication
courses.description: Introduces engineering graphics and fundamentals of computer aided design using the interactive software package AutoCAD on a personal computer.
courses.restrictions: Can enroll if classification is Freshman.

courses.subject: MET
courses.title: Engineering Materials
courses.description: Study of tests used to characterize properties of ceramic, polymeric, and metallic materials and how material properties influence their use and design for engineering applications. Testing procedures demonstrations.
courses.prerequisites: (CHEM 111 [Min Grade: D] and CHEM 113 [Min Grade: D]) or CHEM 101 [Min Grade: D]

courses.subject: MET
courses.title: Introduction to Manufacturing Processes
courses.description: Introduces manufacturing and its managed activities: research and development, production, marketing, industrial relations, and finance. Includes laboratory work in organization, staffing, and operating a model manufacturing enterprise.
courses.prerequisites: MATH 110 [Min Grade: D]
courses.restrictions: Cannot enroll if classification is Freshman or Pre-Junior or Sophomore

courses.subject: MET
courses.title: Computer-Aided Drafting
courses.description: Introduces computer design using an interactive software package on a microcomputer.
courses.restrictions: Cannot enroll if classification is Freshman or Pre-Junior or Sophomore

courses.subject: MET
courses.title: Applied Quality Control
courses.description: Covers variables, procedures, and processes of total quality control within the manufacturing industries. Includes instrumentation for material evaluation, attribute inspection and sampling, supervising for organizational quality improvements, and statistical control. Emphasizes directed laboratory experiences.
courses.prerequisites: STAT 201 [Min Grade: D]
courses.restrictions: Can enroll if classification is Junior or Pre-Junior or Senior.

courses.subject: MET
courses.title: Robotics and Mechatronics
courses.description: Provides a comprehensive technical introduction to robotics and automation in manufacturing. Topics include flow line production, material handling, group technology, and flexible and mechatronics-integrated manufacturing.
courses.prerequisites: (PHYS 153 [Min Grade: D] or PHYS 101 [Min Grade: D]) and MATH 110 [Min Grade: C] or (MATH 121 [Min Grade: C] or MATH 101 [Min Grade: C])

courses.subject: MET
courses.title: Fluid Power
courses.description: Covers the fundamentals of hydraulic/pneumatic systems with an emphasis on applications of Bernoulli's equation. Topics include component types and designs, hydraulic/pneumatic circuit analysis and design of hydraulic/pneumatic systems.
courses.prerequisites: (PHYS 153 [Min Grade: D] or PHYS 101 [Min Grade: D]) and (PHYS 154 [Min Grade: D] or PHYS 102 [Min Grade: D])

courses.subject: MET
courses.title: Applied Mechanics
courses.description: Applications of statics and strength of materials with applications to problems in manufacturing. A combined statics and strength of materials course with applications in manufacturing, including: design of bolted connections, simple structures, and beam design.
courses.prerequisites: (PHYS 154 [Min Grade: D] or PHYS 102 [Min Grade: D]) and MATH 122 [Min Grade: D] and (MET 101 [Min Grade: D] or ENGR 220 [Min Grade: D])

courses.subject: MET
courses.title: Principles of Engineering Design
courses.description: This course is designed to introduce students to the concepts of engineering design. Students will develop a thorough understanding of the design process through collaboratively thinking. This course will allow students to apply iterative design process in creating a new product while integrating the marketing, design, and manufacturing functions of the firm. Students will explore design challenges and employ the product design and development process to design a product to meet the challenge.
courses.prerequisites: MHT 226 [Min Grade: D] and EET 311 [Min Grade: D] and MET 213 [Min Grade: D]

courses.subject: MET
courses.title: Advanced Design Graphics
courses.description: Covers the theory and practice of industry's parts and assembly drawings with a specialization in tolerance and geometric dimensioning. Discusses industrial procedures and standards.
courses.prerequisites: MET 100 [Min Grade: D]

courses.subject: MET
courses.title: HazMat for Manufacturing
courses.description: Covers the characteristics of hazardous substances and wastes, medical surveillance for plant personnel, toxicology, respirators and protective clothing, environmental direct reading indicators, decontamination procedures, and safe working practices.
courses.prerequisites: BIO 161 [Min Grade: D] and CHEM 162 [Min Grade: D] and CHEM 164 [Min Grade: D]
courses.restrictions: Can enroll if classification is Senior.

courses.subject: MET
courses.title: Maritime Manufacturing
courses.description: Provides an overview of the key engineering standards, laws, and regulations governing the construction of commercial vessels in the United States and methods of complying with these requirements. Focuses on the ship manufacturing process and the installation and testing of ship systems.
courses.restrictions: Can enroll if classification is Senior.

courses.subject: MET
courses.title: Advanced Robotics and Mechatronics
courses.description: Covers applied topics related to the integration of computer, robotics, and internet-based automation technologies in modern manufacturing.
courses.prerequisites: MET 205 [Min Grade: D]

courses.subject: MET
courses.title: Computer Numerical Control
courses.description: Discusses theory and application of computer numerical control machines in the manufacturing environment. The laboratory focuses on the programming and operation of CNC machine tools.
courses.prerequisites: (MATH 110 [Min Grade: D] or MATH 121 [Min Grade: C] or MATH 101 [Min Grade: D]) and MET 100 [Min Grade: D]

courses.subject: MET
courses.title: Changing World of 3D Printing and Rapid Prototyping
courses.description: This course is an introduction and survey of rapid-prototyping, especially centered on the advent, impact, and utility of 3D printers and supporting digital technology: computer-aided design (CAD) and computer-aided manufacturing (CAM) software. The course will cover both the concepts and practice of 3D printing and prototyping, emphasizing hands-on work developing computer-based design models (“drawings”) and fabricating prototypes (“parts”) using current tools for desktop manufacturing including 3D printers, laser cutters, desktop engravers, and micromolding and printing. With this knowledge and skill set, students will be able to design, develop and demonstrate a working product suitable for commercialization.
courses.prerequisites: MET 100 [Min Grade: D] or MEM 201 [Min Grade: D]

courses.subject: MET
courses.title: Design for Manufacturing and Assembly
courses.description: One of the final steps in creating a marketable product is the manufacturing of the components. Throughout the design process, engineers must fully understand a variety of processes in which parts can be produced and assembled. Selecting a manufacturing method and ensuring the parts are capable of production is a difficult but critical part of the product design process. This course will allow students to apply the theory of design for manufacturing (DFM) and design for assembly (DFA) to the overall design process. Topics include practical techniques for selection of materials and processes, design considerations for production, manual assembly and automated assembly, and Boothroyd and Dewhurst methods. Students review case studies and analyze production assemblies.
courses.prerequisites: MET 100 [Min Grade: D] and MET 201 [Min Grade: D]

courses.subject: MET
courses.title: Manufacturing Design with CAD
courses.description: Covers design of tools and fixtures for manufacturing, including general-purpose work holders, modular and dedicated fixtures, jigs, fixturing principles, degree of freedom, locating and clamping components, wire frame and solid modeling, and 3d to 2D conversion. Students design models of fixtures.
courses.prerequisites: MET 301 [Min Grade: D]

courses.subject: MET
courses.title: Three Dimensional Modeling
courses.description: Covers three-dimensional design with emphasis on manufacturing and industrial standards. Includes computer-aided-manufacturing using solid, surface, and wire-frame models.
courses.prerequisites: MET 100 [Min Grade: D]

courses.subject: MET
courses.title: Digital Instrumentation
courses.description: Covers digital technology and its application in manufacturing. Covers variables, procedures, and processes of total quality control.
courses.prerequisites: EET 201 [Min Grade: D]

courses.subject: MET
courses.title: Manufacturing Processes
courses.description: Covers a systematic understanding of the operations, applications, and planning of manufacturing processes. Discusses quantitative evaluations of processing parameters influencing product quality.
courses.prerequisites: (MET 101 [Min Grade: D] or ENGR 220 [Min Grade: D]) and MATH 122 [Min Grade: D]

courses.subject: MET
courses.title: MFG Information Management
courses.description: Covers information management in manufacturing. Topics include cost estimation and control, manufacturing resources planning (MRP), just-in-time (JIT), production and inventory controls, management information systems (MIS), supply chain management (SCM), and other advanced information management technology.
courses.prerequisites: MET 205 [Min Grade: D] and MATH 122 [Min Grade: D]

courses.subject: MET
courses.title: Green Manufacturing
courses.description: Covers life cycle analysis, pollution prevention, recycling, and lean manufacturing, including characteristics of hazardous substances and wastes, medical surveillance for plant personnel, toxicology, respirators and protective, environmental direct reading indicators, decontamination procedures and safe working practices for MFG.
courses.prerequisites: CHEM 111 [Min Grade: D] and CHEM 113 [Min Grade: D]

courses.subject: MET
courses.title: Advanced Computer Numerical Control
courses.description: This course covers applied topics related to the integration of computer, CNC machines, and internet-based automation technologies in modern manufacturing.
courses.prerequisites: MET 316 [Min Grade: D]

courses.subject: MET
courses.title: Senior Design Project I
courses.description: This course constitutes the first course of a three-quarter course sequence. It aims to train the students in identifying projects of relevance to the society, in planning and scheduling a solution, and in entrepreneurial activities that may result from the project. The course is also intended to cover an industrial project starting from the proposal writing and conceptual design to final steps. This course is focused on proposal writing.
courses.restrictions: Can enroll if classification is Senior.

courses.subject: MET
courses.title: Senior Design Project II
courses.description: This course constitutes the second course of a three-quarter course sequence and continues MET 421. It aims to train the students in maintaining the progress of a project on schedule, including resolving any team conflicts. It also trains them how to prepare oral, and submit written progress reports. The students supply summary reports to his/her advisor. This course is focused on following standard design steps from the conceptual to final design.
courses.prerequisites: MET 421 [Min Grade: D]

courses.subject: MET
courses.title: Senior Design Project III
courses.description: This is the final installment of a 3 course sequence. The course objective is to train students in a project from the initial conceptual design stage to the preliminary and the final design completion, how to conduct design reviews, and how to document and present findings, design concepts, and conclusion in both oral and written formats. Students are also required to build a working prototype of their final design concept and present it during final presentation of the project.
courses.prerequisites: MET 422 [Min Grade: D]

courses.subject: MET
courses.title: Independent Study in Manufacturing Engineering Technology
courses.description: Self-directed within the area of study requiring intermittent consultation with a designated instructor.
courses.repeatStatus: Can be repeated multiple times for credit

courses.title: Independent Study in Manufacturing Engineering Technology
courses.description: Self-directed within the area of study requiring intermittent consultation with a designated instructor.

courses.subject: MET
courses.title: Special Topics in MET
courses.description: Topics decided upon by faculty will vary within the area of study.
courses.repeatStatus: Can be repeated multiple times for credit

courses.subject: MATE
courses.title: Materials for Emerging Technologies
courses.description: Evolution of materials engineering; education and the profession; concepts, tools, and techniques; selection and design using metals, ceramics, polymers, and composites; application of materials in a technological society; and materials of the future.

courses.subject: MATE
courses.title: Fundamentals of Materials
courses.description: Examines principles underlying structure, properties, and behavior of engineering materials, including metals, ceramics, and polymers. Covers topics including bonding; crystal structure; defect structure; alloying; mechanical, electronic, and magnetic properties in relation to structure; phase equilibria; phase transformations; and oxidation and corrosion. All terms.
courses.prerequisites: CHEM 102 [Min Grade: D] and MATH 122 [Min Grade: D] and PHYS 101 [Min Grade: D]

courses.subject: MATE
courses.title: Modern Materials in Your World
courses.description: This undergraduate level introductory course in modern materials is designed as an elective course for non-engineering majors. It will introduce the field of materials science and engineering while stressing the importance of materials selection in modern day products. In addition, the course will highlight the importance of sustainable materials in product life cycle design in order to minimize environmental effects.
courses.restrictions: Cannot enroll if major is BME

courses.subject: MATE
courses.title: Mechanical Behavior of Materials for Product Design
courses.description: This course introduces Product Design majors to mechanical behavior considerations for materials selection.
courses.restrictions: Can enroll if major is PROD.

courses.subject: MATE
courses.title: Introduction to Polymers
courses.description: Covers polymer molecular structure, polymerization methods, semi-crystalline polymers, glass transition, polymer solution in blends, mechanical properties, and characterization methods.
courses.prerequisites: (MATE 221 [Min Grade: D] or MATE 230 [Min Grade: D]) and CHEM 241 [Min Grade: D]

courses.subject: MATE
courses.title: Fundamentals of Materials
courses.description: Introduces materials and their properties; atomic view and architecture of solids; atomic motion in solids, mechanical, magnetic, electrical and optical properties of materials. Corrosion and degradation of solids.
courses.repeatStatus: Can be repeated 3 times for 16 credits
courses.prerequisites: CHEM 101 [Min Grade: D] and (MATH 121 [Min Grade: D] or MATH 117 [Min Grade: D]) and PHYS 101 [Min Grade: D]

courses.subject: MATE
courses.title: Fundamentals of Materials II
courses.description: This course continues the introduction to materials science and engineering from ENGR 220 by exploring additional topics including phase diagrams, phase transformations, mechanical behavior of materials, thermal properties, environmental considerations and society impacts. In addition, the course introduces concepts of data collection and analysis as it relates to mechanical property testing. The course also addresses techniques for successful technical communication.
courses.prerequisites: ENGR 220 [Min Grade: D] or MATE 220 [Min Grade: D]

courses.subject: MATE
courses.title: Thermodynamics of Materials
courses.description: Covers the fundamental laws of thermodynamics, statistical meaning of entropy, thermodynamic functions, heat capacity, reactions in gases and condensed phases, phase diagrams, solutions, and reaction equilibria in condensed solutions.
courses.prerequisites: (MATE 221 [Min Grade: D] or MATE 230 [Min Grade: D]) and (ENGR 210 [Min Grade: D] or MEM 210 [Min Grade: D])
courses.restrictions: Cannot enroll if classification is Freshman

courses.subject: MATE
courses.title: Kinetics of Materials
courses.description: Covers chemical reaction kinetics, thermodynamics and structure of crystal defects, diffusion equations and numerical methods of solution, kinetics in interfacial phenomena, and diffusional transformations.
courses.prerequisites: MATE 240 [Min Grade: D]
courses.restrictions: Cannot enroll if classification is Freshman

courses.subject: MATE
courses.title: Advanced Materials Laboratory
courses.description: The goal of the course is to introduce students to state-of-the-art experimental techniques for analysis of structure, composition and properties of materials. Electron microscopy, Raman spectroscopy, indentation and thermal analysis will be described.
courses.prerequisites: ENGR 220 [Min Grade: D] or MATE 220 [Min Grade: D]

courses.subject: MATE
courses.title: Processing Polymers
courses.description: Covers polymer processing, viscous flow and melt rheology, injection molding, extrusion, mechanical behavior, and applications and design.
courses.prerequisites: MATE 214 [Min Grade: D]
courses.restrictions: Cannot enroll if classification is Freshman

courses.subject: MATE
courses.title: Defects in Solids
courses.description: Main classes of crystalline defects: vacancies, dislocations, stacking faults, surfaces, grain boundaries, geometry, energy considerations, and movement of defects. Defects in specific crystallographic systems.
courses.prerequisites: MATE 355 [Min Grade: D]
courses.restrictions: Can enroll if major is MSE.

courses.subject: MATE
courses.title: Processing of Ceramics
courses.description: Covers powder production, materials characterization, stability of powder suspensions, rheological and viscoelastic properties of slurries, green-body consolidation, drying, sintering, and structure-property relationships.
courses.prerequisites: MATE 355 [Min Grade: D] (Can be taken Concurrently)
courses.restrictions: Cannot enroll if classification is Freshman

courses.subject: MATE
courses.title: Electronic and Photonic Properties of Materials
courses.description: Electrons, principles of quantum mechanics, bonding, free electrons, and band theory solids; lattice vibrations, electronic and vibrational heat capacity; semiconductors and semiconductor devices; dielectrics, magnetic and optoelectronic materials and devices; superconductivity; applications and implications for energy-harvesting, conversion and storage.
courses.prerequisites: MATE 355 [Min Grade: D] (Can be taken Concurrently)

courses.subject: MATE
courses.title: Structure and Characterization of Crystalline Materials
courses.description: Bonding in solids; classification of metals, semiconductors, and insulators; crystal systems; crystallographic systems in specific engineering materials, relationships, X-ray generation, X-ray absorption and emission; reciprocal space; geometric representation of crystals, small and wide angle scattering, electron microscope imaging and diffraction.
courses.prerequisites: ENGR 220 [Min Grade: D] or MATE 220 [Min Grade: D]
courses.restrictions: Can enroll if major is MSE.

courses.subject: MATE
courses.title: Processing of Metallic Materials
courses.description: Covers solidification processing, casting and welding, heat flow analysis, solid-state transformations, precipitation hardening, transformations in steels, martensite transformations, and industrial case studies.
courses.prerequisites: MATE 245 [Min Grade: D]
courses.restrictions: Cannot enroll if classification is Freshman

courses.subject: MATE
courses.title: Mechanical Behavior of Solids
courses.description: Covers continuum mechanics: three-dimensional stress and strain, hydrostatic and deviatoric components, and isotropic elasticity; Mises yield criterion; fracture criteria; linear elastic fracture mechanics; materials selection; defect-tolerant and defect-free fatigue design; notch effects; and statistics of variation.
courses.prerequisites: (MATE 221 [Min Grade: D] or MATE 230 [Min Grade: D]) and (ENGR 231 [Min Grade: D] or MATH 201 [Min Grade: D] or CAEE 231 [Min Grade: D] or ECE 231 [Min Grade: D])
courses.restrictions: Cannot enroll if classification is Freshman

courses.subject: MATE
courses.title: Materials Selection for Industrial Applications
courses.description: Selection of materials for industrial applications entails a balance between multiple constraints. In this course, students will learn methodologies that consider factors such as material properties, processing techniques, shape, cost, environmental impact, health and safety, and social concerns to determine appropriate materials for industrial applications. Often conflicting constraints that result from these factors need to be evaluated.
courses.prerequisites: MATE 315 [Min Grade: D], MATE 345 [Min Grade: D], MATE 366 [Min Grade: D] (Can be taken Concurrently)

courses.subject: MATE
courses.title: Case Studies in Materials
courses.description: Covers interaction of materials processing and design, materials selection, the design-failure interface, cost and capacity in manufacturing. Taught via case studies.
courses.prerequisites: MATE 370 [Min Grade: D]
courses.restrictions: Can enroll if major is MSE. Cannot enroll if classification is Freshman

courses.subject: MATE
courses.title: Materials for Additive Manufacturing
courses.description: This course addresses additive manufacturing (AM) from a materials science and engineering perspective. Processing, structure, property relationships will be examined for metals, polymers, and ceramics as well as composites used in additive manufacturing. Ideas and concepts from powder processing, solidification processing and welding applicable to AM will be discussed. Critical analysis of the literature and special topics via term projects will be used to provide opportunities for students to explore in depth AM topic areas of their own interest.
courses.prerequisites: ENGR 220 [Min Grade: D] or MATE 220 [Min Grade: D]

courses.subject: MATE
courses.title: The Nuclear Fuel Cycle & Materials
courses.description: Nuclear fuel cycle, including extraction, enrichment, transmutation in a nuclear reactor, reprocessing, waste processing, repository performance. Materials for nuclear reactors, mechanical and thermal performance, radiation damage.
courses.prerequisites: ENGR 220 [Min Grade: D] and (MEM 371 [Min Grade: D] or ECEP 404 [Min Grade: D]) and ECEP 402 [Min Grade: D]

courses.subject: MATE
courses.title: Biomedical Materials
courses.description: Familiarizes students with natural tissues and the implants designed to replace them, treating both components as engineering materials. Includes a review of fundamental topics of materials structure and testing, and case studies.
courses.restrictions: Cannot enroll if classification is Freshman

courses.subject: MATE
courses.title: Advanced Biomaterials
courses.description: Tissue Engineering, matrices, cells, scaffold, engineering properties, constitutive relations, absorbable polymers, cell seeding, cellular isolation, cell-scaffold interaction. May be repeated for credit.
courses.repeatStatus: Can be repeated multiple times for credit
courses.restrictions: Can enroll if classification is Senior.

courses.subject: MATE
courses.title: Engineering Computational Laboratory
courses.description: Covers numerical techniques, finite differences and finite elements, convergence, and applications in engineering design.
courses.prerequisites: (MATE 221 [Min Grade: D] or MATE 230 [Min Grade: D]) and (ENGR 232 [Min Grade: D] or MATH 210 [Min Grade: D] or CAEE 232 [Min Grade: D] or ECE 232 [Min Grade: D]) and MATH 200 [Min Grade: D]
courses.restrictions: Cannot enroll if classification is Freshman

courses.subject: MATE
courses.title: Powder Metallurgy
courses.description: Covers commercial and near-commercial methods of powder making, material and process variables, atomization mechanisms, powder properties and characterization, powder compaction, and properties in the green state.
courses.prerequisites: MATE 366 [Min Grade: D]

courses.subject: MATE
courses.title: Materials Data Analysis
courses.description: Students will learn and exercise common statistical methods for the analysis and interpretation of numerical data in materials science and engineering. Students will also be exposed to the data mining and machine learning techniques applied in materials science and engineering. The course will emphasize providing students fruitful hands-on experience of commonly used platforms to perform (big) data analysis and solve materials-relevant problems.
courses.prerequisites: CIVE 375 [Min Grade: D] or MATE 370 [Min Grade: D]

courses.subject: MATE
courses.title: Recycling of Materials
courses.description: This course will examine the selection criteria for recycling component materials. Recycling involves both reusing materials for energy applications and reprocessing materials into new products.
courses.prerequisites: MATE 240 [Min Grade: D] and MATE 245 [Min Grade: D]

courses.subject: MATE
courses.title: Materials for Energy Storage
courses.description: The course will address principles of operation of electrochemical energy storage devices and describe materials used in those devices.
courses.prerequisites: ENGR 220 [Min Grade: D]

courses.subject: MATE
courses.title: Environmental Effects on Materials
courses.description: Environmental degradation is explored with a focus on electrochemical corrosion reactions in metals and alloys due to atmospheric, aqueous, chemical or elevated temperature exposure. In addition, high temperature degradation of ceramics and degradation of polymers due to exposure to heat, light and chemicals will be addressed. The role of these environmental effects during service and the impact on performance and reliability will be explored.
courses.prerequisites: MATE 245 [Min Grade: D]

courses.subject: MATE
courses.title: Senior Project Design I
courses.description: Introduces the design process, including information retrieval, problem definition, proposal writing, patents, and design notebooks. Includes presentations on problem areas by experts from industry, government, and education.
courses.prerequisites: MATE 280 [Min Grade: D] and MATE 315 [Min Grade: D] and MATE 351 [Min Grade: D]
courses.restrictions: Can enroll if classification is Senior.

courses.subject: MATE
courses.title: Senior Project Design II
courses.description: Continues MATE 491. Requires written and oral progress reports.
courses.prerequisites: MATE 491 [Min Grade: D]
courses.restrictions: Can enroll if classification is Senior.

courses.subject: MATE
courses.title: Senior Project Design III
courses.description: Continues MATE 492. Requires written and oral final reports, including oral presentations by each design team.
courses.prerequisites: MATE 492 [Min Grade: D]
courses.restrictions: Can enroll if classification is Senior.

courses.subject: MATE
courses.title: Independent Study in MATE
courses.description: Self-directed within the area of study requiring intermittent consultation with a designated instructor.
courses.repeatStatus: Can be repeated multiple times for credit

courses.subject: MATE
courses.title: Independent Study in MATE
courses.description: Self-directed within the area of study requiring intermittent consultation with a designated instructor.
courses.repeatStatus: Can be repeated multiple times for credit

courses.subject: MATE
courses.title: Independent Study in MATE
courses.description: Self-directed within the area of study requiring intermittent consultation with a designated instructor.
courses.repeatStatus: Can be repeated multiple times for credit

courses.subject: MATE
courses.title: Independent Study in MATE
courses.description: Self-directed within the area of study requiring intermittent consultation with a designated instructor.
courses.repeatStatus: Can be repeated multiple times for credit
courses.restrictions: Cannot enroll if classification is Freshman

courses.subject: MATE
courses.title: Special Topics in MATE
courses.description: Topics decided upon by faculty will vary within the area of study.
courses.repeatStatus: Can be repeated multiple times for credit

courses.subject: MATE
courses.title: Special Topics in MATE
courses.description: Topics decided upon by faculty will vary within the area of study.
courses.repeatStatus: Can be repeated multiple times for credit

courses.subject: MATE
courses.title: Special Topics in MATE
courses.description: Topics decided upon by faculty will vary within the area of study.
courses.repeatStatus: Can be repeated multiple times for credit

courses.subject: MATE
courses.title: Special Topics in MATE
courses.description: Topics decided upon by faculty will vary within the area of study.
courses.repeatStatus: Can be repeated multiple times for credit
courses.restrictions: Cannot enroll if classification is Freshman

courses.subject: MEM
courses.title: Foundations of Computer Aided Design
courses.description: Covers application of modern, computer-aided graphics techniques and the use of state-of-the-art, computer-aided design/drafting package(s). Includes topics such as principles of computer-aided design/drafting and interactions with computer-aided manufacturing, rapid prototyping, and other modern manufacturing processes; engineering graphics and graphics languages in computer-aided design and/or drafting; creation of a drawing environment; database and file management, editing, modification, displaying, dimensioning, plotting and printing; special editing techniques; 3-D modeling, solid modeling, shading, and rendering; and file transfer. Students must have Sophomore class standing.
courses.restrictions: Cannot enroll if classification is Freshman

courses.subject: MEM
courses.title: Statics
courses.description: Covers two-and three-dimensional vector representation of forces, moments and couples; static equilibrium of particles, rigid bodies, and engineering structures; analysis of external and internal forces in structures via methods of free body diagrams; and properties of cross-sectional areas.
courses.prerequisites: PHYS 185 [Min Grade: D] or PHYS 101 [Min Grade: D]
courses.restrictions: Cannot enroll if classification is Freshman

courses.subject: MEM
courses.title: Introduction to Thermodynamics
courses.description: Introduces thermodynamics from a classical point of view. Covers work, heat, entropy, thermodynamic properties, equations of state, and first and second law analysis of closed systems, control volumes, and selected thermodynamic cycles.
courses.prerequisites: MATH 122 [Min Grade: D] and PHYS 101 [Min Grade: D]

courses.subject: MEM
courses.title: Fluid Mechanics I
courses.description: Covers general physical properties of a fluid; kinetics of fluid motion; material derivative, vorticity, strain, and dynamics of fluids; and derivation of conservation laws in control volume form with applications.
courses.prerequisites: (MATH 200 [Min Grade: D] or MATH 189 [Min Grade: D]) and MEM 202 [Min Grade: D] and MEM 310 [Min Grade: D]

courses.subject: MEM
courses.title: Mechanics of Materials I
courses.description: Covers definitions of stress and strain, uniaxial loading, torsion, bending moments and shear forces in beams, bending stresses and shear stress in beams, and stress transformation.
courses.prerequisites: MEM 202 [Min Grade: D]
courses.restrictions: Cannot enroll if classification is Freshman

courses.subject: MEM
courses.title: Dynamics
courses.description: Covers kinematics and kinetics in two and three-dimensional space, force and acceleration, linear and angular momentum, and energy methods.
courses.prerequisites: (MATH 189 [Min Grade: D] or MATH 200 [Min Grade: D]) and MEM 202 [Min Grade: D]
courses.restrictions: Cannot enroll if classification is Freshman

courses.subject: MEM
courses.title: Introduction to Controls
courses.description: Introduces the concepts of modeling of mechanical, electrical, electromechanical, thermal, and hydraulic systems; linearization; state-space model; time-domain analysis; transfer functions; frequency-domain analysis; analysis of systems involving automatic control of position, speed, power, flow, pressure, temperature, and other physical quantities; basic concept of feedback; basic concept of stability; computer-aided analysis.
courses.prerequisites: MEM 238 [Min Grade: D] and (MATH 201 [Min Grade: D] or MATH 261 [Min Grade: D] or ENGR 231 [Min Grade: D]) and (MATH 210 [Min Grade: D] or MATH 262 [Min Grade: D] or ENGR 232 [Min Grade: D])
courses.restrictions: Cannot enroll if classification is Freshman

courses.subject: MEM
courses.title: Thinking Like a Mechanical Engineer
courses.description: Covers introductory data gathering, presentation, evaluation, and analysis. Students will acquire logic and programming skills by using spreadsheets and engineering analysis software tools. In-class assignments, mini-design problems, hands-on experiments, and computer-based activities are used to work with data and collaboratively solve more difficult problems that lead them to think like a mechanical engineer.
courses.repeatStatus: Can be repeated multiple times for credit

courses.subject: MEM
courses.title: Introduction to Mechatronics for Mechanical Engineers
courses.description: Mechatronics is an interdisciplinary field that combines principles of mechanical engineering, electronics, computer science, and control theory to design and build automated systems. Students will learn in the intersection between hardware elements (i.e., sensors, actuators, and microprocessors) and software elements (i.e., software and control theory) and create their own mechatronics device. Mechatronics is an essential foundation for the expected growth in automation and manufacturing.
courses.repeatStatus: Can be repeated multiple times for credit
courses.prerequisites: PHYS 102 [Min Grade: D] and MATH 201 [Min Grade: D] and MEM 161 [Min Grade: D] and (ENGR 131 [Min Grade: D] or ENGR 132 [Min Grade: D])

courses.subject: MEM
courses.title: Introduction to Biomechanical Engineering
courses.description: An overview of the application of mechanical engineering to biological systems. Covers basic anatomy and physiology; tissue, joint, cell, and protein mechanics; joint kinematics; biofluid mechanics; biothermodynamics; biotransport; biomimetic controls; and biomanufacturing.
courses.prerequisites: MATH 200 [Min Grade: D] and PHYS 101 [Min Grade: D] and CHEM 102 [Min Grade: D] and BIO 141 [Min Grade: D]

courses.subject: MEM
courses.title: Thermodynamic Analysis I
courses.description: Covers second law of thermodynamics as applied to closed systems, control volumes, and thermodynamic cycles (Carnot); entropy and isentropic relationships; gas (Otto, Diesel, Stirling, Ericsson, Brayton), vapor (Rankine), and refrigeration cycles.
courses.prerequisites: ENGR 210 [Min Grade: D] or MEM 210 [Min Grade: D]
courses.restrictions: Cannot enroll if classification is Freshman

courses.subject: MEM
courses.title: Thermal  Fluid Science Laboratory
courses.description: Introduces modern laboratory techniques, including statistical analysis of experimental data; thermodynamic properties and equations of state; and dynamic and static temperature measurements with potentiometers, bridge circuits, and oscilloscopes. Fall.
courses.prerequisites: MEM 220 [Min Grade: D] and MEM 310 [Min Grade: D]
courses.restrictions: Cannot enroll if classification is Freshman

courses.subject: MEM
courses.title: Fluid Dynamics I
courses.description: Covers equation of motion for compressible flow; static, total, and stagnation concepts; one-dimensional isentropic, normal shock, including Fanno and Rayleigh flows and choked flow; two-dimensional supersonic flow, including Prandtl-Meyer flow and oblique shocks; analysis and design of compressible flow devices, including supersonic nozzles, diffusers, wind tunnels, inlets, and combustors.
courses.prerequisites: MEM 220 [Min Grade: D]
courses.restrictions: Cannot enroll if classification is Freshman

courses.subject: MEM
courses.title: Fluid Mechanics II
courses.description: Covers differential analysis of fluid flow, including the Euler’s equations, potential flows, and the Navier-Stokes equations; angular momentum and its application to turbomachinery; external flow and boundary layers, and an introduction to compressible flow.
courses.prerequisites: MEM 220 [Min Grade: D]

courses.subject: MEM
courses.title: Mechanics of Materials II
courses.description: Reviews mechanics of materials, beam theory, combined loading, stress transformation, shear center, asymmetrical bending, deflection of beams, statically indeterminate beams, energy methods, inelastic bending, and beam column instability.
courses.prerequisites: MEM 230 [Min Grade: D]
courses.restrictions: Cannot enroll if classification is Freshman

courses.subject: MEM
courses.title: Experimental Mechanics I
courses.description: Covers static testing methods, including strain gages, extensometers, photoelasticity, and model analysis; practical applications of experimental stress analysis; and verification of standard materials tests, including tensile, shear, and buckling. Winter. Some or all pre-requisites may be taken as either a pre-requisite or co-requisite. Please see the department for more information.
courses.prerequisites: MEM 238 [Min Grade: D] (Can be taken Concurrently) and MEM 230 [Min Grade: D]
courses.restrictions: Cannot enroll if classification is Freshman

courses.subject: MEM
courses.title: Mechanical Behavior of Materials
courses.description: Introduces the deformation and failure of engineering materials; Emphasizes application of the fundamentals to engineering design to prevent failure; Covers material damage and failure under multi-axial stresses, yielding, fracture mechanics, fatigue crack growth, fatigue life estimation, and deformation and failure of composite materials.
courses.prerequisites: MEM 230 [Min Grade: D]
courses.restrictions: Can enroll if classification is Junior or Pre-Junior or Senior.

courses.subject: MEM
courses.title: Heat Transfer
courses.description: Covers fundamentals of conduction, convection, and radiation; steady and unsteady heat conduction; fundamentals of boundary layer flows; introduction to forced and free convection for external and internal flows; blackbody radiation; and radiation and surface radiation properties.
courses.prerequisites: ENGR 210 [Min Grade: D] and (MEM 220 [Min Grade: D] or CIVE 320 [Min Grade: D]) and (MATH 210 [Min Grade: D] or MATH 262 [Min Grade: D] or ENGR 232 [Min Grade: D])
courses.restrictions: Cannot enroll if classification is Freshman

courses.subject: MEM
courses.title: Dynamic Systems Laboratory I
courses.description: Includes experiments involving modeling and simulation of linear and non-linear dynamic systems, including feedback controls. Spring.
courses.prerequisites: MEM 255 [Min Grade: D]
courses.restrictions: Cannot enroll if classification is Freshman

courses.subject: MEM
courses.title: Performance Enhancement of Dynamic Systems
courses.description: This course introduces measures of performance of dynamical systems, means of computing/evaluation-of such measures, and how to design controllers to improve performance.
courses.prerequisites: MEM 255 [Min Grade: D]

courses.subject: MEM
courses.title: Numerical Methods in Mechanical Engineering Design
courses.description: Understand and implement numerical methods to solve Mechanical Engineering problems with the aid of a digital computer. Problems will be drawn from all fields of interest to mechanical engineers, including solid and fluid mechanics, heat transfer, robotics, aerodynamics and orbit mechanics, systems dynamics, and control. The course will cover numerical methods such as roots of equations, linear algebraic equations, systems of nonlinear equations, optimization, curve fitting, integration, and differential equations. Python will be used as a programming language.
courses.repeatStatus: Can be repeated multiple times for credit
courses.prerequisites: MATH 201 [Min Grade: C], MATH 210 [Min Grade: C] (Can be taken Concurrently) or (ENGR 131 [Min Grade: C] or ENGR 132 [Min Grade: C])
courses.restrictions: Can enroll if major is MECH or major is MSE.

courses.subject: MEM
courses.title: Engineering Reliability
courses.description: Reviews probability concepts and modeling of random phenomena, including parameter estimation, empirical determination of distribution models, catastrophic failure models, material strength and fatigue life distribution, and reliability improvement.
courses.prerequisites: MATH 290 [Min Grade: D] or MATH 201 [Min Grade: D] or MATH 261 [Min Grade: D] or ENGR 231 [Min Grade: D]
courses.restrictions: Can enroll if classification is Junior or Senior.

courses.subject: MEM
courses.title: Introduction to Nuclear Engineering I
courses.description: Introduces the fundamental scientific, technical, social and ethical issues in nuclear engineering; nuclear reactions and readiation, radiation protection and control, nuclear energy production and utilization, nuclear fuel cycle, nuclear fuel cycle, nuclear materials, controlled fusion and thermonuclear plasma systems, basics of plasma physics and plasma chemistry, nuclear waste management, nuclear reactor safety, analysis of severe nuclear accidents, risk assessment and related issues of engineering ethics.
courses.prerequisites: PHYS 201 [Min Grade: D] and (ENGR 210 [Min Grade: D] or CHE 206 [Min Grade: D])

courses.subject: MEM
courses.title: Space Systems Engineering I
courses.description: Introduction to space engineering through presentation of two topics that serve as the foundation of space systems analysis and design: rocket propulsion and orbital mechanics.
courses.prerequisites: MEM 220 [Min Grade: D] and MEM 238 [Min Grade: D] and MEM 310 [Min Grade: D]

courses.subject: MEM
courses.title: Space Systems Engineering II
courses.description: Introduction to design principles and theory of satellite systems engineering, including design theories and parameters involved in satellite development, as well as real life conditions such as applications, product assurance, assembly, and testing.
courses.prerequisites: MEM 373 [Min Grade: D]

courses.subject: MEM
courses.title: Hess Undergraduate Scholars Research
courses.description: A change for undergraduates to experience independent research as part of the MEM Hess Honors Program. Weekly group meetings to discuss the details of the research endeavor are coupled with independent student in a research laboratory. May be repeated five times for credit.
courses.repeatStatus: Can be repeated 5 times for 18 credits
courses.prerequisites: MEM 310 [Min Grade: D]

courses.subject: MEM
courses.title: Internal Combustion Engines
courses.description: Covers engine types and trends, thermodynamics of engines and engine processes, ideal and actual engine processes and cycles, combustion and emissions, fuel chemistry and properties, detonation and knock, and engine testing and performance.
courses.prerequisites: MEM 310 [Min Grade: D]
courses.restrictions: Cannot enroll if classification is Freshman

courses.subject: MEM
courses.title: Power Plant Design
courses.description: Covers heat cycle arrangement, equipment selection, analysis of cost demands, and diversity factors. Includes economic studies of plant and cycle arrangements.
courses.prerequisites: MEM 310 [Min Grade: D]
courses.restrictions: Cannot enroll if classification is Freshman

courses.subject: MEM
courses.title: Gas Turbines & Jet Propulsion
courses.description: Covers fundamentals of thermodynamics and aerothermodynamics, and application to propulsion engines; thermodynamic cycles and performance analysis of gas turbines and air-breathing propulsion systems, turbojet, turboprop, ducted fan, ramjet, and ducted rocket; theory and design of ramjets, liquid and solid rockets, air-augmented rockets, and hybrid rockets; aerodynamics of flames, including the thermodynamics and kinetics of combustion reactions; supersonic combustion technology and zero-g propulsion problems; and propulsion systems comparison and evaluation for space missions.
courses.prerequisites: MEM 220 [Min Grade: D] and MEM 310 [Min Grade: D]

courses.subject: MEM
courses.title: Principles of Combustion I
courses.description: Covers thermochemistry, the relationship between heats of formation and bond energies, heat capacity and heats of reaction, chemical equilibrium, calculation of flame temperature, and composition of burned gas.
courses.prerequisites: MEM 410 [Min Grade: D]
courses.restrictions: Cannot enroll if classification is Freshman

courses.subject: MEM
courses.title: Principles of Combustion II
courses.description: Covers laminar flame propagation in premixed gases, detonation and deflagration, burning of liquid and solid fuels, and diffusion flames.
courses.prerequisites: MEM 405 [Min Grade: D]
courses.restrictions: Cannot enroll if classification is Freshman

courses.subject: MEM
courses.title: Thermodynamic Analysis II
courses.description: Covers thermodynamic analysis of ideal and real mixtures and gas phase reacting systems; Maxwell relations; chemical and phase equilibrium; air-conditioning; and combustion.
courses.prerequisites: MEM 310 [Min Grade: D]
courses.restrictions: Cannot enroll if classification is Freshman

courses.subject: MEM
courses.title: HVAC Loads
courses.description: Human comfort and associated models; state-of-the-art methods of calculating building peak heating and cooling loads; analysis of different psychrometric processes; different types of secondary systems: description, operating principles, modeling, simulation and sizing of secondary systems.
courses.prerequisites: MEM 345 [Min Grade: D] and (MEM 310 [Min Grade: D] or AE 220 [Min Grade: D])
courses.restrictions: Cannot enroll if classification is Freshman

courses.subject: MEM
courses.title: HVAC Equipment
courses.description: Standard and real, single-stage multistage refrigeration cycles; vapor compression components (compressor, expansion devices, condensers, and evaporators); heat pumps; absorption systems; boilers; heat exchangers; cooling coils, cooling towers; part-load energy performance; annual energy; annual energy estimation methods (degree-day, bin method, modified degree-day).
courses.prerequisites: MEM 345 [Min Grade: D] and (MEM 310 [Min Grade: D] or AE 220 [Min Grade: D])
courses.restrictions: Cannot enroll if classification is Freshman

courses.subject: MEM
courses.title: Fuel Cell Engines
courses.description: Introduces fundamental aspects and operating principles of fuel cell systems, including: basic electrochemical principles, thermodynamics required for understanding the operation, components including functions and materials, electrochemical performance characteristics, analysis of system losses and efficiency, various fuel cell types, current state of technology, application areas/implementation, and current technical challenges.
courses.prerequisites: (MEM 220 [Min Grade: D] or CHE 302 [Min Grade: D] or CIVE 320 [Min Grade: D]) and MEM 310 [Min Grade: D]

courses.subject: MEM
courses.title: Introduction to Microfabrication
courses.description: This course focuses on the fundamentals of microfabrication technologies. The materials, principles, and applications of silicon-based microfabrication technologies such as photolithography, wet/dry etching, deposition techniques, surface micromachining, and polymer micromachining are covered. This course also includes two lab sessions through which students have hands-on experiences in microfabrication.
courses.restrictions: Can enroll if classification is Junior or Senior.

courses.subject: MEM
courses.title: Microfluidics and Lab-on-a-Chip
courses.description: This course focuses on design, manufacturing, and application of lab-on-a-chip systems as well as understanding microfluidic phenomena. The lecture covers novel microfluidic phenomena, microsensors, microactuators, and case studies. This course also includes two lab sessions through which student have hands-on experiences in lab-on-a-chip technology.
courses.prerequisites: MEM 417 [Min Grade: D]
courses.restrictions: Can enroll if classification is Junior or Senior.

courses.subject: MEM
courses.title: Aerodynamics
courses.description: Covers steady and unsteady flow, flow around a body, wing theory, thin airfoil theory, fundamental equation of finite-wing theory, and aerodynamic characteristics of wings. Introduces potential theory and boundary layer phenomena.
courses.prerequisites: MEM 220 [Min Grade: D]
courses.restrictions: Cannot enroll if classification is Freshman

courses.subject: MEM
courses.title: Mechanics of Vibration
courses.description: Covers free and forced vibrations of one-, two-, and multiple-degree-of-freedom systems; continuous systems; and transient and random vibration problems. Includes use of digital computer for homework and special class problems.
courses.prerequisites: MEM 238 [Min Grade: D] and (TDEC 222 [Min Grade: D] or ENGR 232 [Min Grade: D] or MATH 210 [Min Grade: D] or MATH 262 [Min Grade: D])
courses.restrictions: Cannot enroll if classification is Freshman

courses.subject: MEM
courses.title: Biomechanics
courses.description: Introduces modeling of dynamics of biomechanical systems.
courses.prerequisites: MEM 202 [Min Grade: D] and MEM 238 [Min Grade: D]
courses.restrictions: Cannot enroll if classification is Freshman

courses.subject: MEM
courses.title: Aircraft Design & Performance
courses.description: Introduces aerodynamics and airfoils; steady flight; power required and power available curves; range and endurance; takeoff, glide, and landing; stick force and control-free stability; moment coefficients and derivatives; and designing to specification. Students must have Junior class standing.
courses.restrictions: Can enroll if classification is Junior or Senior.

courses.subject: MEM
courses.title: Aerospace Structures
courses.description: Covers properties of wing and fuselage sections, torsion of thin-walled and skin-stringer multiple-cell sections, non-symmetrical bending of wing and fuselage sections, shear in thin-walled and skin-stringer sections, and buckling. Introduces matrix methods.
courses.prerequisites: MEM 230 [Min Grade: D]
courses.restrictions: Cannot enroll if classification is Freshman

courses.subject: MEM
courses.title: Finite Element Methods
courses.description: Introduces the fundamental theory and formulations of finite element method and its application in structural mechanics and thermal/fluid science. Topics include formulation of 1-D and 2-D elements, isoparametric elements, static and dynamic analysis of trusses, beams, and frames, 2-D plane problems, and heat transfer problems.
courses.prerequisites: MEM 230 [Min Grade: D]

courses.subject: MEM
courses.title: Introduction to Composites I
courses.description: Introduces anisotropic elasticity, lamina stiffness and compliance, plane stress and strain, test methods, and failure criteria.
courses.prerequisites: MEM 330 [Min Grade: D]
courses.restrictions: Cannot enroll if classification is Freshman

courses.subject: MEM
courses.title: Introduction to Composites II
courses.description: Covers laminated plate theory, stiffness and compliance of laminated plates, effect of laminated configuration on elastic performance, and strength production.
courses.prerequisites: MEM 428 [Min Grade: D]
courses.restrictions: Cannot enroll if classification is Freshman

courses.subject: MEM
courses.title: Advanced Stress Analysis
courses.description: Examines three-dimensional representation of stress and strain, coordinate transformation, stress strain relationships for anisotropic and isotropic materials, equilibrium equations, boundary value problems, governing equations in plane strain and plane stress problems, Airy's stress function, two-dimensional problems in polar coordinates, and selected applications to stress analysis problems in mechanical engineering.
courses.prerequisites: MEM 330 [Min Grade: D]
courses.restrictions: Cannot enroll if classification is Freshman

courses.subject: MEM
courses.title: Machine Design I
courses.description: Covers static strength and fatigue theories of failure, fasteners, welded joints, springs, roller bearings, and lubricated spur gears.
courses.prerequisites: MEM 202 [Min Grade: D] and MEM 230 [Min Grade: D] and MEM 238 [Min Grade: D]
courses.restrictions: Cannot enroll if classification is Freshman or Junior or Pre-Junior or Sophomore

courses.subject: MEM
courses.title: Introduction to Computer-Aided Design and Manufacturing
courses.description: Covers fundamental use of CAD/CAM systems for geometry definition, finite element applications, and introductory computer graphics concepts.
courses.prerequisites: MEM 201 [Min Grade: D]
courses.restrictions: Can enroll if classification is Junior or Senior.

courses.subject: MEM
courses.title: Introduction to Computer-Aided Manufacturing
courses.description: Examination of the basic elements that are used to integrate the design and manufacturing processes. Robotics computerized-numerical controlled machine, and CAD/CAM systems. Manufacturability considerations when integrating unit process elements.
courses.prerequisites: MEM 201 [Min Grade: D] and MEM 435 [Min Grade: D]
courses.restrictions: Cannot enroll if classification is Freshman

courses.subject: MEM
courses.title: Manufacturing Process I
courses.description: Examines the basic elements used to integrate the design and manufacturing processes; robotics, computerized-numerical-controlled machines, and CAD/CAM systems; and manufacturability considerations when integrating unit process elements.
courses.prerequisites: MEM 220 [Min Grade: D] and MEM 230 [Min Grade: D]
courses.restrictions: Cannot enroll if classification is Freshman

courses.subject: MEM
courses.title: Manufacturing Process II
courses.description: Covers plastics and reinforced plastics processes, theory of polymer and plastic process, simple models of polymer flows, and manufacturability of plastics.
courses.prerequisites: MEM 437 [Min Grade: D]
courses.restrictions: Cannot enroll if classification is Freshman

courses.subject: MEM
courses.title: Thermal Systems Design
courses.description: This course covers fundamentals of thermal system design; the role of design in engineering practice; economic analysis used for design of thermal systems; advanced concepts and analysis of heat exchangers and distillation equipment; modeling of thermal systems; simulation of thermal systems; fundamentals of optimization and design of optimized thermal systems.
courses.prerequisites: MEM 345 [Min Grade: D]
courses.restrictions: Cannot enroll if classification is Freshman

courses.subject: MEM
courses.title: Biofluid Mechanics
courses.description: This course introduces flow-related anatomy and pathophysiology, and biomedical flow devices and their design challenges. Analysis methods to solve biological fluid mechanics design problems are introduced and several interdisciplinary team projects are assigned to apply fluid mechanics to practical biological or medical problems.
courses.prerequisites: MEM 220 [Min Grade: D] or BMES 451 [Min Grade: D]

courses.subject: MEM
courses.title: Solar Energy Fundamentals
courses.description: This course focuses on basic theories of solar radiation, solar thermal energy, and photovoltaics. Students will learn basic radiation heat transfer, solar radiation, solar thermal collection and storage, passive and active solar heating/cooling, physics of photovoltaic cells, and characteristics and types of solar cells.
courses.prerequisites: MEM 345 [Min Grade: C] and PHYS 201 [Min Grade: C]

courses.subject: MEM
courses.title: Fundamentals of Plasmas I
courses.description: Introduces the fundamentals of plasma science and modern industrial plasma applications in electronics, fuel conversion, environmental control, chemistry, biology, and medicine. Topics include quasi-equilibrium and non-equilibrium thermodynamics, statistics, fluid dynamics and kinetics of plasma and other modern high temperature and high energy systems and processes.
courses.prerequisites: PHYS 201 [Min Grade: D] or TDEC 201 [Min Grade: D] or PHYS 112 [Min Grade: D] or PHYS 187 [Min Grade: D]

courses.subject: MEM
courses.title: Fundamentals of Plasmas II
courses.description: Continues the development of the engineering fundamentals of plasma discharges applied in modern industrial plasma applications in electronics, fuel conversion, environmental control, chemistry, biology, and medicine. Topics include quasi-equilibrium and non-equilibrium thermodynamics, statistics, fluid dynamics of major thermal and non-thermal plasma discharges, operating at low, moderate and atmospheric pressures.
courses.prerequisites: MEM 446 [Min Grade: D]

courses.subject: MEM
courses.title: Applications of Thermal Plasmas
courses.description: Introduces applications of modern thermal plasma processes focused on synthesis of new materials, material treatment, fuel conversion, environmental control, chemistry, biology, and medicine. Topics Include thermodynamics and fluid dynamics of high temperature plasma processes, engineering organization of specific modern thermal plasma technologies.
courses.prerequisites: PHYS 201 [Min Grade: D] or TDEC 201 [Min Grade: D] or PHYS 112 [Min Grade: D] or PHYS 187 [Min Grade: D]

courses.subject: MEM
courses.title: Applications of Non-Thermal Plasmas
courses.description: Application of modern non-thermal plasma processes focused on synthesis of new materials, material treatment, fuel conversion, environmental control, chemistry, biology, and medicine. Topics Include non-equilibrium thermodynamics and fluid dynamics of cold temperature plasma processes, engineering organization of specific modern non-thermal plasma technologies.
courses.prerequisites: PHYS 201 [Min Grade: D] or TDEC 201 [Min Grade: D] or PHYS 112 [Min Grade: D] or PHYS 187 [Min Grade: D]

courses.subject: MEM
courses.title: Orbital Mechanics
courses.description: Introduces two-body problems, satellite orbits, their characterization and determination; transfer maneuvers between orbits; path planning for inter-planetary travels.
courses.prerequisites: MEM 238 [Min Grade: D]

courses.subject: MEM
courses.title: Aircraft Flight Dynamics & Control I
courses.description: Covers general equations of motion for aircraft; linearization based on small disturbance theory and modal analysis to identify longitudinal open-loop characteristics; review of classical control theory; state space analysis; and autopilot design, including classical, pole placement, and optimal.
courses.prerequisites: MEM 355 [Min Grade: D]
courses.restrictions: Cannot enroll if classification is Freshman

courses.subject: MEM
courses.title: Aircarft Flight Dynamics & Control II
courses.description: Covers observers; lateral dynamics; Dutch roll, roll convergence, and spiral modes; autopilot design and evaluations; and inertial cross-coupling computer simulation and analysis.
courses.prerequisites: MEM 453 [Min Grade: D]
courses.restrictions: Cannot enroll if classification is Freshman

courses.subject: MEM
courses.title: Introduction to Robotics
courses.description: Introduces basic concepts in robot operation and structure, including actuators, sensors, mechanical components, robot control and robot programming.
courses.prerequisites: MEM 238 [Min Grade: D] and MEM 255 [Min Grade: D]
courses.restrictions: Cannot enroll if classification is Freshman

courses.subject: MEM
courses.title: Robotics II
courses.description: Covers homogeneous kinematics of robots; velocities and accelerations; and static forces in manipulators, including iterative Newton-Euler formulation of manipulator dynamics.
courses.prerequisites: MEM 455 [Min Grade: D]
courses.restrictions: Cannot enroll if classification is Freshman

courses.subject: MEM
courses.title: Robotics III
courses.description: Covers robotic-based automated manufacturing, including robot work cell configurations, applications of robots in manufacturing, material transfer, assembly, and inspection.
courses.prerequisites: MEM 456 [Min Grade: D]
courses.restrictions: Can enroll if classification is Senior.

courses.subject: MEM
courses.title: Micro-Based Control Systems I
courses.description: Provides hands-on experience in real-time control and manipulation of hardware dynamic systems, including microcomputer, architecture, software, and device drivers. Emphasizes real-time interfacing of data acquisition and control systems.
courses.prerequisites: MEM 355 [Min Grade: D]
courses.restrictions: Cannot enroll if classification is Freshman

courses.subject: MEM
courses.title: Control Applications of DSP Microprocessors
courses.description: Continues MEM 458. Provides real-time control and manipulation of hardware dynamic systems. Emphasizes real-time interfacing of data acquisition and control systems. Topics include Code Composer Studio, Microprocessor C programming, Pulse width modulation (PWM), Quadrature encoder pulse (QEP) circuits, DSP system control and interrupts, Digital loop systems, design of PID digital controllers, design of digital controllers in state space, microcomputer controller implementation, sensors and actuators, and implementation of digital controllers in microprocessors.
courses.prerequisites: MEM 458 [Min Grade: D]
courses.restrictions: Cannot enroll if classification is Freshman

courses.subject: MEM
courses.title: Introduction to Engineering Management
courses.description: Introduces the general theory of management, including the processes of planning, organizing, assembling resources, supervising, and controlling.
courses.restrictions: Can enroll if classification is Junior or Senior.

courses.subject: MEM
courses.title: Medical Robotics I
courses.description: Use of robots in surgery, safety considerations, understanding robot kinematics, analysis of surgeon performance using a robotic devices, inverse kinematics, velocity analysis, acceleration analysis, various types of surgeries case study.
courses.prerequisites: MEM 238 [Min Grade: D]

courses.subject: MEM
courses.title: Medical Robotics II
courses.description: Force and movement for robot arms, robot dynamics, computer vision, vision based control, combining haptics, vision and robot dynamics in a cohesive framework for the development of a medical robotic system.
courses.prerequisites: MEM 475 [Min Grade: D]

courses.subject: MEM
courses.title: Haptics for Medical Robotics
courses.description: Introduction to haptics, physiology of touch, actuators, sensors, non-portable force feedback, portable voice feedback, tactile feedback interfaces, haptic sensing and control.
courses.prerequisites: MEM 238 [Min Grade: D]

courses.subject: MEM
courses.title: Computer-Aided Tissue Engr
courses.description: Introduction to the engineering aspects of tissue reengineering and integrated CAD/CAE/CAM technology applied to tissue engineering with hands-on experience combing CAD, medical image processing, 3-D reconstruction software, and solid freeform fabrication of tissue scaffolding.
courses.restrictions: Can enroll if classification is Senior.

courses.subject: MEM
courses.title: Senior Design Project I
courses.description: Introduces the design process, including information retrieval, problem definition, proposal writing, patents, and design notebooks. Includes presentations on problem areas by experts from industry, government, and education. The Senior Design sequence (MEM 491/492/493) should be taken in the students’ final year in the BSME program.
courses.prerequisites: MEM 435 [Min Grade: D] and (MEM 331 [Min Grade: D] or MEM 351 [Min Grade: D] or MEM 311 [Min Grade: D])
courses.restrictions: Can enroll if classification is Senior.

courses.subject: MEM
courses.title: Senior Design Project II
courses.description: Continues MEM 491. Requires written and oral progress reports.
courses.prerequisites: MEM 491 [Min Grade: D]
courses.restrictions: Can enroll if classification is Senior.

courses.subject: MEM
courses.title: Senior Design Project III
courses.description: Continues MEM 492. Requires written and oral final reports, including oral presentations by each design team at a formal Design Conference open to the public and conducted in the style of a professional conference.
courses.prerequisites: MEM 492 [Min Grade: D]
courses.restrictions: Can enroll if classification is Senior.

courses.subject: MEM
courses.title: Independent Study in Mechanical Engineering & Mechanics
courses.description: Self-directed within the area of study requiring intermittent consultation with a designated instructor.
courses.repeatStatus: Can be repeated multiple times for credit

courses.description: Self-directed within the area of study requiring intermittent consultation with a designated instructor.

courses.subject: MHT
courses.title: Kinematics
courses.description: Study of four-bar linkages, sliders, and other devices using orthogonal of vectors, instantaneous centers, equivalent linkages, and effective cranks. Graphic solutions are emphasized, including an introduction to computer software.
courses.prerequisites: PHYS 153 [Min Grade: D]
courses.restrictions: Cannot enroll if classification is Freshman or Sophomore

courses.subject: MHT
courses.title: Thermodynamics I
courses.description: Students are introduced to the general theory of heat and matter; laws of thermodynamics; energy-transformation principles and availability of energy; and properties and processes for substances and ideal gases.
courses.prerequisites: (PHYS 153 [Min Grade: D] or PHYS 101 [Min Grade: D]) and MATH 122 [Min Grade: D]

courses.subject: MHT
courses.title: Thermodynamics II
courses.description: First and second law analysis of power cycle components. Analysis of gas power cycles, including Otto & Diesel engines and Brayton cycle turbines. Analysis of traditional power plant cycles, including Rankine, Refrigeration and heat pump.
courses.prerequisites: MHT 205 [Min Grade: D]

courses.subject: MHT
courses.title: Technology Laboratory I
courses.description: Conduct experiments to determine the physical properties of incompressible fluids and to measure the flow rates of velocities utilizing pilot tubes, office plates, Venturi and Weirs flow meter, U-tube differential manometers and piezometers. Some or all pre-requisites may be taken as either a pre-requisite or co-requisite. Please see the department for more information.
courses.prerequisites: MHT 301 [Min Grade: D] (Can be taken Concurrently)
courses.restrictions: Can enroll if classification is Junior or Senior.

courses.subject: MHT
courses.title: Applied Statics
courses.description: Explores forces, moments, couples, statistics of particles, and rigid bodies in two and three dimensions. Examines external and internal distributed forces, first moments and centroids, and structures such as trusses, frames and machines.
courses.prerequisites: PHYS 282 [Min Grade: D] and MATH 122 [Min Grade: D]

courses.subject: MHT
courses.title: Applied Dynamics I
courses.description: This course deals with the motion of bodies under the action of a single or multiple forces. It covers kinematics and kinetics of particles in rectilinear and curvilinear motions using various coordinate systems, work and energy, impulse and momentum, planar kinematics using analytical and graphical methods. Kinetics of rigid bodies using force and acceleration, work and energy, and impulse and momentum principles.
courses.prerequisites: MET 213 [Min Grade: D]

courses.subject: MHT
courses.title: Applied Dynamics II
courses.description: Impulse and momentum of particles; kinematics and dynamics of rigid bodies-force-mass and acceleration; dynamics of rigid bodies - work and energy. Impulse and momentum; introduction to mechanical vibration.
courses.prerequisites: MHT 222 [Min Grade: D]

courses.subject: MHT
courses.title: Measurement Techniques and Instrumentation
courses.description: The course focuses on basic concepts of measurement and measurement systems and techniques, causes of errors and error propagation; uncertainty analysis, data collection and analysis using statistical methods, data acquisition systems; Knowledge delivery is based on integrated experiential learning modules involving various measurement sensors and instruments.
courses.prerequisites: (PHYS 154 [Min Grade: D] or PHYS 102 [Min Grade: D]) and EET 209 [Min Grade: D] and STAT 201 [Min Grade: D]

courses.subject: MHT
courses.title: Environmental Control Plasma Laboratory
courses.description: The course presents engineering principles of non-thermal plasma application to air cleaning from Volatile Organic Compounds by combining hands-on laboratory experience with lectures. The students learn the engineering and physical principles of non-equilibrium plasma systems using the unique pulsed corona system of the Drexel Plasma Institute Environmental Laboratory.
courses.prerequisites: CHEM 111 [Min Grade: D] and CHEM 113 [Min Grade: D]

courses.subject: MHT
courses.title: Fluid Mechanics I
courses.description: Examine hydrostatics; principles governing fluids at rest; pressure measurement; hydrostatic forces on submerged areas and objects; simple dams. Discuss fluid flow in pipes under pressure; fluid energy; power and friction loss; Bernoulli's theorem. Flow measurement.
courses.prerequisites: MHT 205 [Min Grade: D] and MET 213 [Min Grade: D] and MET 209 [Min Grade: D]

courses.subject: MHT
courses.title: Applied Strength of Materials I
courses.description: Topics include axially loaded members, stress and strain, allowable stresses, factor of safety, temperature effects, indeterminate members, torsional stresses and deformation. Students also examine shear moment beams; and flexural and transverse shearing stresses in beams.
courses.prerequisites: MHT 222 [Min Grade: D]

courses.subject: MHT
courses.title: Applied Strength of Materials II
courses.description: A study of determinate and indeterminate bean deflections and reactions by superposition, integration and moment area methods. Topics include combined stresses; principal stresses; Mohr's circle; and theories of failure.
courses.prerequisites: MHT 310 [Min Grade: D]

courses.subject: MHT
courses.title: Thermo and Heat Transfer Analysis
courses.description: Explores basic thermodynamic and heat transfer concepts and relations including fundamental of conduction, convection, and radiation using modern experiential methods to analyze thermodynamics systems and the related heat transfer mechanisms.
courses.prerequisites: MHT 205 [Min Grade: D]

courses.subject: MHT
courses.title: Fluid Mechanics Laboratory
courses.description: Conduct experiments to determine the physical properties of incompressible fluids and to measure the flow rate of velocities as the fluid flows through open channels, partially filled conduits, conduits under pressure, pipe networks, and turbines and pumps.
courses.prerequisites: MHT 301 [Min Grade: D]

courses.subject: MHT
courses.title: Mechanical Design I
courses.description: An introduction to mechanical design, the design process, design factors, creativity, optimization, human factors, and value engineering. Topics include simple design, properties and selection of materials; stress concentrations; strength under combined stresses; theories of failure; impact; and fluctuating and repeated loads.
courses.prerequisites: MET 100 [Min Grade: D] and MET 213 [Min Grade: D]

courses.subject: MHT
courses.title: Mechanical Design II
courses.description: Topics include deformation and design of belt drives, chair drives, detachable fasteners and bearings, lubrication, and journal bearings. Covers stresses and power transmission of spur, bevel, and worm gear, shaft design, and clutches and brakes.
courses.prerequisites: MHT 401 [Min Grade: D]

courses.subject: MHT
courses.title: Fluid Mechanics II
courses.description: Consider pipe networks and reservoir systems, flow in open channels and uniform flow energy, friction loss, minor losses, velocity distribution, alternate stages of flow, critical flow, non-uniform flow, accelerated, retarded flow and hydraulic jump.
courses.prerequisites: MHT 301 [Min Grade: D]

courses.subject: MHT
courses.title: Advanced Materials
courses.description: Lectures on inorganic materials, i.e., polymers, glasses, ceramics, concrete, wood, and materials having important electrical and magnetic properties; also a summary of the most up-to-date applications for the fabrication and uses of both metals and nonmetals.
courses.prerequisites: MET 101 [Min Grade: D]
courses.restrictions: Can enroll if classification is Senior.

courses.subject: MHT
courses.title: HVAC
courses.description: Heating, Ventilation, and Air Conditioning (HVAC) focuses on air conditioning principles, including psychometrics and heat pumps. Examines calculation of heating and cooling loads in accordance with ASHRAE practices, principles of gas compression, analysis of vapor compression; refrigeration systems, low temperature refrigeration cycles, and absorption refrigeration systems.
courses.prerequisites: MHT 206 [Min Grade: D]
courses.restrictions: Can enroll if classification is Senior.

courses.title: Special Topics in MHT
courses.description: Topics decided upon by faculty will vary within the area of study.
courses.repeatStatus: Can be repeated multiple times for credit
